content.text: I'm kind of enjoying the cadence of a nightly big protest, speeches, 9 minutes of silence on a bridge in portland, then more speeches... then the crowd things, the police get upset that somebody touches their fence and attack everybody. Last night they started using this LRAD sound weapon. There's actually no pretense that the protesters doing anything beyond shaking the fence, throwing empty water bottles, and graffiti. It's kind of sadly ironic, if the police stopped attacking people then people might not be so sure they need reform.
Solid first post!
That's a wonderful offer.... here's [some pictures](%gZj+rR76yPn42ocxcuArOAoOVY7QJNa/85Af9asZGTw=.sha256) of my protest from a few days ago... been going every night.

This is a tricky problem and something we've had to deal with [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) as well. What we did was hook up zendesk sdk for reporting posts. Every message can be reported regardless if they came through our pub.  From zendesk we can add hashes to a block list on a server which our pub's check so they stop relaying that feed if that's what we want. In terms of the app, we process the feed then put it in a sqlite database. There's a check system to find which content has been labeled objectionable and blocked. We were hoping to get #gabbygrove working but haven't been able to get full support so we're using the legacy feed format . We felt Apple's rules are about being able to see the content in the app instead of if it exists in the database somewhere. 

I'll cc [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) and [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) who've been doing this work.  Getting type:delete and type:edit i think are important because it's much better for people to delete / edit things from their own feed than to have some service do it. 

We're not done with getting all of the planetary system working, and can't put in the app store til it's all working. We've not yet had any content which we had to block, flag, or delete. 

I don't know how to explain to apple that you're not controlling things if you run pub's. [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519)'s option of going towards DHT invites, rooms, and no pubs as a service totally works, but i think we'll lose users in the on boarding process.

[@rchaves](@VUgbo/ihmVWgh7szFJcG0Tg395T5/8JU0jijEVmyByU=.ed25519)

Hey, we'd be happy to share / collaborate on the blocking service.. i could see us having different policies but there's no reason to duplicate effort... we could figure out how to have something blocked in feedless and not planetary or vice versa... i know we'd benefit from being able to direct people to a web interface... 

I see this as something where everybody making ssb apps wins if we can get the protocol to get more adoption and users.

[@adria0](@ZFWw+UclcUgYi081/C8lhgH+KQ9s7YJRoOYGnzxW/JQ=.ed25519)

Hey, were you the person at 36c3 who was talking about creating an archive database to make like a search engine backup for activist websites that was p2p? I'm wanting an ssb search engine / backend for planetary... i thought your stuff might work, but i might be confused.
Yeah, i'm struggling with how many games there are in this bundle...  It'll take weeks to just download and try each one, and who has time with that with all the protesting.

What's the state of #patchql? We're running a version of ssb-viewer at planetary.link, which is fine, but it's pretty limited. I was thinking it'd be cool to have a slick react front end to it.  I saw [@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) did a [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVqUSi9XxnE) a couple weeks ago, but the [code](https://github.com/sunrise-choir/ssb-patchql) hasn't been updated in 4 months. Where it at? Maybe  [@Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519) or [@mikey](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519) knows?

Here's some of what we're thinking of in terms of design for planetary.link. The stuff being done with feedless.social is super interesting, but building a UI like this would be easier with react.  I'm not quite sure how to handle keys with reading / login when we don't store them on the sever... but seems like a worthy goal. 

![Desktop.png](&hLvDl26Wq0sfOCDsT7K1f73Lkg/ZmRCmAX2zFktZ3hQ=.sha256)
![Desktop Search.png](&VLdT9jpeZOPNQYqyrdN4qrKdzVQiAqAOg9ZRcDdk8LU=.sha256)

Planetary's business model is pretty the same as [new vector](https://vector.im/) which builds and maintains [riot.im](https://riot.im) and does services and hosting for companies or governments who want to use matrix. 

We'll do hosted service for multi-user publishers who want to publish content on ssb where we manage and keep their keys safe. We'll do payment processing and content gateways for people who want to charge access to join their private groups, for member only / subscription content. For individual users, we'll provide cloud hosting of content, similar to how you can view instagram on the web and how you use dropbox / google cloud / icloud for back up of content so it's not all on your phone. Probably helping folks make pretty website around their ssb content the way facebook pages / wordpress / etc work.

It's been talked about in the past plenty but i'm happy to answer any questions.

Hey [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) it's something I noticed recently, the code is simply an installation of the [code on ssbc](https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-viewer). But you're right, i did modify the code to change the link back to Planetary, you can find the modifications [here](https://planetary.link/.well-known/ssb-viewer.tar.gz). 

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) and I noticed that it wasn't honoring the publicHosting flag. But we aren't able to find the code running at [viewer.,scuttlebot.io](viewer.,scuttlebot.io), so it's clearly also in violation of the AGPL.  

I'm not a member of ssbc so i can't fix the released code, but you should definitely go find out who's running viewer.scuttlebot.io in complete and flagrant violation of the AGPL. ;-D
yeah, somebody should update the github version. ;-D

[@okdistribute](@hCDeKTwEhhhNXtg00adkMDi+tx6qrRApFFj49QBM3lY=.ed25519) 

I heard through the grapevine that there's going to be some report on security / privacy and secure scuttlebutt coming to decentpatterns.xyz? I'm guessing it's negative since there are some real security and privacy problems with ssb. 

I'm curious to learn more.

-rabble

[@Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519) do you think a ssb-viewer update could be built on it? run it on a sever, present graphql... it'd of course not support posting and shouldn't share private messages. 

ps, [@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519)  & [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) I've pulled in the code from git-ssb, posted it in public on the planetary [github repo](https://github.com/planetary-social/ssb-viewer), and am working on getting the publicwebhosting flag respected. Thanks for pointing out the source. 

I think this just again shows the need for private groups and also the various implementations to not pass on requested data if the requester is not within a few degrees of separation from the feed being requested. If bad stuff can happen with old code and misconfigured servers, just imagine malicious actors.

I must be confused, because the name of the project sounded so similar to solar. it was a decentralized cloud back up system made for activists so we didn't lose movement websites. 

I hate it when i forget to bookmark things. ;-D

There's only so much you can do, but this is what we did for our [privacy policy](https://planetarysupport.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/categories/360002326834-Rules-Policies). 

In terms of longer term work, i think the real solution is to create a commons model of governance so communities of people could enact these things instead of the service provider.  

GabbyGrove works, and has implementations in go and node for ssb, but the plugins don't all work and the main ssb apps like manyverse, patchwork, patchbay don't support it. I think oasis  might and of course planetary does.  We just had to get planetary out there and couldn't wait for everybody to slowly adopt it. If you helped push it i think it'd help a lot. Nobody's objecting to it just because not prioritizing the work. 

Personally i'm most excited about earthstar because that lets us do multiple devices, delete, ephemeral content, etc...

Welcome [@Ari Rodriguez](@yoZN+y/crk4Gvb4bJ48QIUAhMXlJFaYFiAddc7oItww=.ed25519) it's great to have more folks in the community with deep crypto knowledge. I noticed you did some shamir secret sharing, we've had an ssb project which worked on that for key backup, #dark-crystal.

The delete we're talking about is a soft delete, where you leave the content on the feed and in your replicated databases but you don't display it to the user because the author has requested it. With #gabbygrove you can do a stronger delete where you actually stop hosting the content and replicating it, because it's signed by not embedded in the log.

Last year [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) add the ability to actually remove all the feed content when you block somebody, so you're not longer keeping a copy of content from somebody you blocked. That's not quite the same thing as delete. 

There are proposals like [@cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519)'s #earthstar which is similar to but not ssb which would allow for proper ephemeral content and delete. Again, even then it doesn't prevent anybody from keeping a copy of the data around.

So we're close to having it working in [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) but we were using the "type": "dropContentRequest" and "hash":  "%2LM6gN66H/wyw7TcQmkw9kECTZVjyDo66B99TjS16VU=.sha256" format. 

I'm going to poke around today and see if i can't get support for your delete message type in to planetary.

I think we might want to ask [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) / [@cryPhone📱](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) as he's the person who developed it and chose that message type.
This might be a dumb question, but is it in English?

Getting private groups is so huge! Thanks [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519), [@keks](@YXkE3TikkY4GFMX3lzXUllRkNTbj5E+604AkaO1xbz8=.ed25519), [@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519), [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519), and everyone else who's been doing the heavy lifting work to make this happen.
[@Raydegroat](@AMlISFSCmpphzoC9wOaMOvvnNW8BB0I+9ri4vG5Qz54=.ed25519) it tastes great!

I've been thinking about how to show users some examples of interesting content on scuttlebutt to help them find their community and provide and example of how to use the app. My feeling is that we model our behavior in a space off of what we see. So to communicate culture we've got to show it to people. 

I was having people autofollow [@The Weekly](@iVPi/B73hJSpsUB8XbSnlxe3NembPXLjOfIexlYdgJA=.ed25519) but [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) isn't updating it any more. We also are auto following [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519)'s [@Current Events](@wNmXqk80DL4FrBjzZcYqbKs/SpsPv6MVX6BLICabPfI=.ed25519), the [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519), and myself. This was a somewhat random choice of content. 

But as we get close it'd be cool to actually pick some things. So any ideas of some good feeds which might show off a breadth of interesting things in the scuttleverse?

[@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519) You mean the quotes on the site about manyverse? Those are cool, but that's not what i'm asking. 

I'm looking for ideas of people / feeds who would like to opt-in to having their content shown in our explore tab, it's similar to extended network in patchwork. Interesting people or content which highlights the scuttleverse.

[@cblgh](@C6fAmdXgqTDbmZGAohUaYuyKdz3m6GBoLLtml3fUn+o=.ed25519) explore is really popular and widely used on instagram and twitter. I find it useful on patchwork and oasis, it's more interesting actually because it's friends of friends. 

Patchwork does suggested followers which is an interesting idea, it's also common feature on twitter/instagram/facebook. 

Peer invites seem cool, but the process of finding a friend, generating the invite, getting it from them, putting it in the right spot will lose a lot of people. That's why folks use the same account name on various services, just "I'm rabble on twitter or Instagram" is something you can tell a person. Even something like, follow me on scuttlebutt, i'm "@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519" isn't going to work. Once i saw somebody post a slide deck with their ssb ident but i wasn't able to copy it correctly. Something like [WebFinger](https://webfinger.net/) that the fediverse uses is better, you give somebody a domain or email and they can present all of your identities on various services. 

I've been using SSB for a few years now and often struggle with invites. I use patchwork, patchbay, oasis, planetary, ssb-cli, and manyverse. Of those i can't really tell you without searching or reading the docs how to generate an invite. I'm pretty sure manyverse has it, but i haven't been able to find it, haven't looked so hard, but i'm guessing DHT invites. I know how to do use pub invite, not peer, in patchwork. But i couldn't generate one for somebody to follow me.

What we have now is you install any ssb app and you get an empty screen with a kind of antisocial message saying go find your own way. The goal is to be bridged in to people's friends, but that's not what we do right now. What we do is bridged in to the center of a which ever pub happens to accept new users at the moment. 

My goal is to have a privacy preserving way of doing contact matching. A service, which can be run decentralized if we figure out how, where you can register your peer invites, or direct invites with a way of finding your device when you're online like over #tor, #yggdrasil, #i2p, rooms, or #cjdns. If somebody can show they are connected to me elsewhere then i let them get the invite from this service. 

But that's not what i'm asking here at all. What i want to know is there anybody who would want to opt-in to being being preloaded in the app as a example of what kind of community and posts people might expect to find on ssb. Right now we pre-filter with whatever random joined the pub you randomly choose at signup.

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519)

Hey, i'm looking for some ssb accounts which make sense to pre-load but not not follow for planetary. My idea is we update them with each build for new users so they've got something on the extended network / explore tab. You've got a good mix of personal / photo / scuttlebutt content. 

Is it something you'd consider being ok with? My goal is provide examples of content, people to follow as a way of communicating more about the practices of communities on ssb. It's not something i'd want to do without consent of course. Thoughts?

Hey [@󠁪󠁯󠁥󠁹Joey](@BCM6DHYJvWzwWi1lFl2tjDXjaqyZAEmJH5ZONSpXhtc=.ed25519),

I'm not sure how closely you're following planetary. I really like your posts of food, your land, off grid stuff and tech... I'm looking for some good examples of ssb people to pre-load in to our explore tab on planetary. The idea is we'd make a script which downloaded your feed when we do a build, then we'd load it but not auto follow people. That way when they look on the explore tab they find examples of interesting people and content which they could choose to follow. If they  don't follow then the preloaded feed won't update.

Is this something you'd be ok with us doing, including your feed preloaded in to the app?

thanks,
rabble

Hey [@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519)

I was wondering if you'd be willing to let us include your feed pre-loaded into planetary for new users to see when they go to the explore tab. They wouldn't be autofollowing you, but it would give people and example of how to use ssb and some insight in to the ssb ecosystem. I strongly feel that users model their behavior after what they see.

I like how you mix in personal, photos, fungi, and tech... Feels very much the essence of what the scuttleverse is. What do you think?

Oi [@Luandro](@2RNGJafZtMHzd76gyvqH6EJiK7kBnXeak5mBWzoO/iU=.ed25519)!

Espero que você esteja bem com a pandemia e sua família. I'm getting ready to launch planetary and i wanted to preload some ssb content in to our explore tab. To show what kind of things people are using ssb for and give folks an example of how to use scuttlebutt. What we do is pull the feed and store it in json and then load when a new user installs the app. They wouldn't be auto-subscribed but it would give people something to see and play when when they first install. If they like it they can follow you.

I wound't do it if you don't want, but i think you provide a really great perspective on many things which are the heart of the scuttlebutt project. What do you think?

Hey [@Angelica](@eANNuLfzX/9rlGODXHYV8WJb+zw2h+d7YsT4vpYPvD0=.ed25519)

I'm reaching out to people like yourself who really represent the values and practices of the scuttlebutt community. We're getting ready to open up planetary and we'd like to highlight some people in our explore tab. Our idea is to pre-load the feed in to the app so when people click on the explore tab there's interesting things to read and see. I think if we show behavior of how people use ssb then they'll take that on and start picking up on the communities values. 

We wouldn't auto-follow you, just give folks a chance to know you're there and see your work. Then they can follow if they want. If you don't feel comfortable of course we'd never include you without your consent. 

thanks,
rabble
Hey [@gwil](@PEqxT8YRvrkf2fyjAgTl8pmdo8aR4KVsKLyh0b5JyOE=.ed25519) yeah we've had lots of bugs. Do you mind trying it again?

[@SoapDog](@gaQw6z30GpfsW9k8V5ED4pHrg8zmrqku24zTSAINhRg=.ed25519)

hey i'm looking for folks to pre-load their feed in to planetary for the discover tab... it doesn't auto follow them, but does provide some examples off ssb content for new users... you've got a nice mix of coffee pictures and coding posts... are you interested in having one of your feeds included?

Let's find ways to get more indieweb stuff in to ssb... we're using a viewer for planetary at planetary.link and i think that what i'd like is to build that viewer, either hosted on our servers or self hosted, to have more indie web features to bridge the two. 

I'd love to exploring working together but we're on a shoe string budget at the moment while we try and get planetary out the door and raise our seed round.

I keep looking at things like athena, roam, notion, and thinking that there could be a neat way of building something which was a mix of knowledgebase / wiki but also with some database driven apps. What i want is a rewrite of protest.net where you have some of the site being a collaborative knowledge base and some of it being a  more structured events listing. Kind of like what would be a mix of meetup and a wiki. 

Athena looks like it might be something which could be used this way. But it also could be done in a decentralized way building on earthstar type stuff.
Thanks so much. There is always such weird energy around this, it's a constant frustration. I appreciate your willingness  to be included as having a good example of how to use SSB helps so much.

These are some great questions [@haileycoop](@QdKPBH4vZne0DqD+v1mVJgeeOg8y3RxWuomT7pvIfEA=.ed25519). I want to thank you for asking in a way which helps figure things out and talk about them instead of generating more conflict.  I'm writing with the [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) identity but this is 

I think there are so many levels of governance to consider. There's the ssbc protocol level, lowest level, who decides what gets incorporated as standard. Then there is the affordances of the protocols and implementations which have governance through code as law. Then there are the front end apps which are promoted and which are used. They've got all sorts of power dynamics, norms, and rules built in to them. There aren't any closed source SSB apps that i know of, now that planetary is open source, but even then, who decides which PR's get merged, how well managed is forking if the creators aren't behaving. 

In terms of Planetary, it's a company with some investors. Their main power is in their ability to provide more money if needed, as they've not go any board seats for the company and the founding shares have 20x voting rights. It gives me in theory control similar to what zuckerberg has on facebook over the company. That power is only real if the economic side of the company works, ie there's enough money coming in to cover all the costs related to running and growing the business. 

There are a few commitments which i think keep planetary accountable. One is users own their identity and can move it off of the application if they want. You can download your data from centralized social media platforms, but you can't keep using them, you lose your relationships. Being able to switch apps and keep everything working is huge. If Planetary the company stops behaving well then you can leave. What's more, you can take the app and fork it. There's some services which would have to be setup around push notifications and the like so there is a cost, but it's possible unlike centralized systems.

Being a public benefit corp (not done but in progress) is another way of saying, the company will hold itself accountable and do a public audit of it's role in the world. 

The real solution is not so much constraints on planetary as a company, rather having a more vibrant community beyond the company building, maintaining, and supporting the ecosystem. 

Personally i'm quite keen on what [@cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519) is doing with #earthstar and could see at some point in the future switching to using that as the default for planetary. It's purely speculative but that would be a big shift. If folks liked planetary focused on SSB and didn't want earthstar, i'd hope they'd take the code and keep maintaining that fork. 

I think the tricky part is how to balance out the few people who know enough and do enough work to shift the fundamentals with that power. How do we praise and value work being done, while communicating it's implications so various levels of user communities can be involved in co-designing the technology. We've got lots of informal power, which isn't necessarily bad, but needs to be acknowledged.

[@Ari Rodriguez](@yoZN+y/crk4Gvb4bJ48QIUAhMXlJFaYFiAddc7oItww=.ed25519) Have you see the work of [@Haskell Guy](@f5ABjSMAR95ajlGST63/xx+XUoty53mlSZZ3GhGbQeE=.ed25519)
and his [Haskell implementation of scuttlebutt?](https://git.sr.ht/~haskell-guy/ssb-haskell )

[@pat](@JUBGIPQ3KzZEqc03FX53bZucL9i/UqgHQgpPyJHPzpw=.ed25519), I'm pretty sure that won't happen. NZ has no plans to open up tourism to places that have any community transmission until there is a vaccine deployed locally. They are operating on a  mandatory 2 week quarantine system upon arrival. For now all 6500 spots are taken by citizens and residents and even then they're having to control the rate of people entering the country. Once there is capacity for citizens and permanent residents they'll open up to long term work visa holders and essential workers / essential industry support. For those people the government plan is to charger them the full cost of quarantine, around $10,000 NZD. 

There's between 100,000 and 200,000 residents and citizens who are currently overseas who the government expects to resettle back in NZ. They're adding capacity but carefully because there's been a few slip ups with infected arrivals leaving quarantine early. At current rate it'll take about a year just to handle returning citizens. 

There will be no international tourism to NZ until late 2021 or 2022.

[@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519) & [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) Just wanted to follow up. 

Thanks for the links, i've updated it so it respects the public web hosting flag and we're working on giving users an option in planetary to set it with the next release.
Or we could fix it so we're not hostile to users.

Yeah, we should do that on the basic level of each ssb implementation. Doesn't mean couldn't change the code, but by default it'd be a huge help.

I really like the idea of this, we need better ways of 'find us on ssb' where you're pulled in to a community who's invited you instead of a single follower. That it's a private group is much much better as it doesn't expose all the important meta data about the social graph without wanting to. 

> [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519): "While I am very excited about this idea, since private groups are private, I would take more time to carefully think about the privacy issues (IP address leakage) of using the DHT for this…"

The leaking of ip addresses worries me in general, i'd love a default way to open connections to people which wasn't ip address based. Be it tor, i2p, yggdrasill, cjdns...

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) I've heard problems with Tor in terms of battery performance on mobile but i think this is our best bet, there's a pure [js tor mplementation](https://github.com/Ayms/node-Tor). Connecting to a DHT to find an onion router address doesn't create nearly the privacy hole that an ip address would create.
I wish tactics like this would still work in the US. At this point the police would just start clipping wires or some right wing chud would just plow their cars in to the blockade.

> if we’re getting into details @Rabble, one thing you need to consider is how to remove people from a group. Back end, this is not possible - once a person has a group key they have it. Front end you can “remove” a person from a group and mint a new group which continues on … and perhaps publish a message which signals that backlink, but that hasn’t been spec’d explored yet.

Yeah, i've assumed for a while that we'd have rolling groups. Where when you needed to remove someone you had to roll the keys and re-invite. In the case of matrix rooms this rolling happens all the time. 

> An exciting new implication of groups is you can now ask to replicate based on who’s in your groups rather than just by who your follows are. There’s a bootstrapping problem there, but I’m pretty excited. In #ahau at the moment in fact, the only follows we use are the ones auto-generated by a pataka (pub) invite. That + 2 hops + replicate people in your groups and you’re off.

Isn't that essentially what apple does with their remote wipe? https://support.apple.com/guide/icloud/erase-a-device-mmfc0ef36f/icloud

They even have the signed messages transiting over a mesh peer to peer gossip network so the device you want to wipe never has to directly added to the internet, as long as it gets within mesh wifi distance of a device which has heard the delete order.

Yeah, [@moid](@Sur8RwcDh6kBjub8pLZpHNWDfuuRpYVyCHrVo+TdA/4=.ed25519) i'm not saying an open and not corporate controlled version isn't a bad idea. It's a good idea. But we could learn a lot from how apple does it.
Interesting pattern you're using, i think we really need better curation / collection creation / sharing tools in SSB.
Doesn't the start of the quarantine seem like so long ago?

We've been using element for all of the twitter Blue Sky project and a few activist tech projects i've been involved with. There's some barriers to getting folks on board. 

What seems to work is to say "We've got a chat app which is like slack but with privacy and encryption. Go to element.io, create an account, and tell us what the account name is." Then we take that and invite them. Never once has somebody gotten the @username:matrix.org part right, they always just give the username part and we have to figure it out. Kind of makes usernames and federation tricky.

Once people get it installed and use it we're getting the same engagement as slack except that element doesn't do a good as job at notifications to draw people back in to the conversation.

[@mjb](@sN5GWx7gMkJBNnSboUk+jszL3G/0uAN3o3k13PfD+r4=.ed25519)

Hey can we include your feeds in the preloaded feeds for Planetary?

I think we don't display tags right. You've got to click through to see them in patchwork, first we show show which tags a post has been given instead of a tags button. Then we also need the tags option to show a feed of taggings. So which tags have been added to what content by your network. If you have that it'd be super useful .

#### Gravatar like service for SSB?

What do folks think about a service which is like [gravatar](https://en.gravatar.com/) for scuttlebutt / earthstar identities? Obviously because gravatar is closed source we'd want to use something like [Libravatar](https://www.libravatar.org/) created for the fediverse.

As far as i can tell, the avatar services would work just as well for public ssb identities as they would for email addresses as they're both an md5 hash of a string. With both gravatar and libravatar you confirm your email or login with oauth/openid. The SSB way of doing that is either signing something with your private key or writing something to your log.

I think it'd be nice to optionally be able to get somebody's avatar and current about messages super quickly. Thoughts?

I'm not using manyverse day to day, so perhaps it's got ui around this, but in patchwork there's not easy way to  see the rooms broken out, with a list of people in the room. If we had that then we'd be able to see them and it'd really make sense out of them. That would then make it make sense to have hosted rooms.

Being able to setup hosted rooms is something we've considered doing as planetary.

Yeah, we wanted to make the pubs we run feel like transparent relays. But i think we went to far and do need to expose them in the pubs menu so it's clear they're out there allowing users to see it, unfollow, block, etc... 

Unless somebody makes a PR for it, i'll try and get that in to the next release myself.

[@cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519) you're an inspiration to me and we're all incredibly lucky to share this time and space with you. Your work on abuse / harassment for scuttlebutt has been fundamental and i've got such high hopes for what you've done with EarthStar. 

I'm sorry i can't do more to help and support you.

Yeah, moving is a lot of work, but also the US just seems to be getting to be more of a nightmare. My personal plan is to go to Uruguay, where i used to live, for a while, and then on to New Zealand. Unfortunately although I have a residency class work visa it's not the same thing as residency and therefore i'm not on the list of people allowed to enter the country through the limited quarantine capacity. 

For folks working overseas, there's a few options, you could be a freelancer or even w2 employee in the US but live overseas, there are a few countries like Estonia, Georgia, and i believe Barbados who have specific remote worker covid visas. Another option is the DAFT visa to the Netherlands, which is pretty easy to get and would cover a lot of software developers. 

One thing worth remembering is that american companies pay software developers much more than any place else. I've often puzzled as to why, my guess is that it's probably due to a lot of the tech companies in the US being created by developers themselves and therefore prioritizing the field as valuable. Then other companies have to pay more to compete.

Reading [@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519)'s post about minimum wage i went and did some research...

So after taxes, a minimum wage worker in the US makes $13,900 USD. In New Zealand a full time minimum wage worker makes $21,610 USD. The Kiwi of course gets 4 weeks of vacation and health care with is never provided to an American worker who makes minimum wage.  The US system is actually setup so that you do get some welfare and support from the government if you make less than about $40k. It's perverse because for every dollar you make more than the minimum $13.9k they take away about one dollar in other services. There's little difference between making $15k and $35k if you're able to access all the services. 

Comparing cost of living, across the country as a whole, which we know is a bit tricky because prices vary a lot.

#### Indices Difference
* Consumer Prices in New Zealand are 0.98% higher than in United States
* Consumer Prices Including Rent in New Zealand are 5.98% lower than in United States
* Rent Prices in New Zealand are 19.34% lower than in United States
* Restaurant Prices in New Zealand are 6.60% lower than in United States
* Groceries Prices in New Zealand are 2.69% lower than in United States
* Local Purchasing Power in New Zealand is 20.53% lower than in United States

The only one which sticks out there is the PPP which i think is skewed because the US has way more people who make a ton of money, and more working poor. Where as in NZ has a narrower income distribution.

Average wealth is easy to skew if you have very wealthy people. If Bezos enters a room with 175 who have no money, then the average wealth of everybody in the room is $1 billion USD. 


What Dominic says about adjusting to the people around you in terms of spending really resonates with me.  It's really shifted how much i've spent and hasn't had a huge effect on my happiness or wellbeing. Knowing this hasn't made it easier to act on it.
Next build allows image / media attachments to replies. It's something patchwork, and i think manyverse have supported for a while.

That sucks, but as [@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519) says it looks like that's OC not CS. We've gotten very familiar with all the myriad of chemical weapons that the state has bee using on us. 

If you have this happen to you, there are sudecon wipes you can carry in your medical kit for protests which really help. Other than that water or saline solution is probably best. Once you get home cover every part of the body with dish soap. It's an oil and liquid dish soap breaks it down. I usually leave it on for 15 minutes, no rubbing, just keep it on. Be very careful as it'll be all over your clothes and anything you touch. No making out with comrades until everybody has been fully decontaminated and changed clothing!!!! Similarly be very careful if you need to use the bathroom after a potential exposure... you can guess why the burning would not be wanted.

After you've got soap over everything, take a cold or luke warm shower. Hot shower will open our pores and that's bad news. 

In Portland it's now normal for there to be OC, CS, and a few others to be spread in the are over many city blocks. 

Here's a picture of me getting a direct OC spray in the face, i had no idea it was coming and was not wearing any protection except prescription glasses. 

![Screen Shot 2020-10-05 at 6.56.17 PM.png](&BcZGAz1B2yzb3daZf9z+wRWTIJG0MHqvtNzBkEb3fpA=.sha256)

![Screen Shot 2020-10-07 at 11.18.51 AM.png](&Qe3qgXH+Bnv25mj2/0r+fPWgMKyOUfsZYyGwYnnGvU0=.sha256)
So sorry for your loss... i was devastated when my dad passed. I make a point of keeping talking to him, because it keeps him in my life even though i know he's passed.

content.text:
We've been looking at how to solve a couple issues with Planetary, with the hope that it'd be useful the rest of SSB around two issues.

How to map a user defined name to an identity. And how to do it in a decentralized way which is consistent with ssb's values of offline and local first. 

To do this we're thinking about webfinger and DID's to map identities to keys. This is similar to [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519)'s ideas of using a room for it. You could have multiple labels for a single identity. One system falls back to a room being online, another to dns and a server. Neither are perfect.

But we found a step needed before we can do the webfinger -> DID mapping. We need to be able to authenticate to a web service using your SSB identity without an authentication server. Basically, using your ssb apps as the source of authority for logging in to services. 

To explore this we've been talking with Fission, a group of folks working on top of the ipfs ecosystem. They've got this thing called [UCAN decentralized authorization standard])(https://whitepaper.fission.codes/identity/id-overview). Seems like it'd be useful for making SSB identities things you can use to access other services. 


There's [a working session Wednesday 9pm PDT](https://talk.fission.codes/t/portable-usernames-dids-and-distributed-auth-with-ucan/1074) online where we'll work through how we might get the pieces to fit together. If this is interesting to other SSB folks it'd great to expand the conversation.
The mix of languages on these feeds is annoying. I think maybe we need to break out a different way of defining content vs people feeds.

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) & [@rchaves](@VUgbo/ihmVWgh7szFJcG0Tg395T5/8JU0jijEVmyByU=.ed25519) what did you guys put in for your apple appstore [export compliance documentation](https://help.apple.com/app-store-connect/#/dev88f5c7bf9). I'm pretty sure that libsodium's crypto is export restricted.
Yeah, so i saw the open source exemption, which covers Planetary too, i guess anything using libsodium.

The photos are good, i don't know, just using it how you want. 

We've been having continuing problems with scheduling to pubs.

# Funding the arts: a request for funds for artist grants

Hello, handshake council!
[@Zach!](@ZqH7Mctu/7DNInxuwl12ECjfrAKUX2tBLq1rOldNhg0=.ed25519) and I would like to roll out an initiative to invite artists to make art in the SSB space. The idea is to invite some folks to make SSB-inspired art, whether that's as a reaction to exploring the P2P space, culture, or the protocol itself.

We've got $628.68 euros in our discretionary fund at the moment. We would like to give each artist $500 euros to create something special in this space. If we support four artists in total, that comes to $2K euro, so **we are requesting $1,371.32 euros.**

Where should this come from? In [the current budget](%Mn/kVU4CeL4lweGCGgxg0BxixFRVZnkFVymzITQB6GE=.sha256), the "general buffer" has $6K in it. This would work nice! Or there another fund that everyone thinks would work?

Today I decided to use some time to implement a _preferences_ system for #fafi-browser. It turned out quite simple but useful for other people developing Racket apps:

```lisp
#lang racket/base

(require racket/file)

(provide (all-defined-out))

(define data-folder (let ([data-f (simplify-path
                                   (build-path
                                    (find-system-path 'pref-dir) 'up "fafi-browser"))])
                      (begin
                        ;; DANGER: side-effect
                        (make-directory* data-f)
                        data-f)))

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; PREFERENCES SYSTEM
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
(define preferences-file (build-path data-folder "fafi.rktd"))

(define (set-pref name value)
  (put-preferences (list name)
                   (list value)
                   #f
                   preferences-file))

(define (get-pref name [default-value #f])
  (get-preference name
                  (lambda () default-value)
                  'timestamp
                  preferences-file))

(define (set-default-pref name default-value)
  (let ([v (get-pref name 'unset)])
    (when (equal? v 'unset)
      (set-pref name default-value))))

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; Default preferences
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(set-default-pref 'homepage "gemini://gemini.circumlunar.space")



;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; MAIN (just help testing stuff)
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
(module+ main
  (displayln data-folder)
  (displayln preferences-file))

```

Using it from the `preferences-window%` of Fafi is damn easy.

```lisp
(define homepage-field
  (new text-field%
       [label "Homepage"]
       [parent panel]
       [init-value (get-pref 'homepage)]))
```

At the moment I don't have much to persist on the app, so the preferences window look quite empty:

![image.png](&q6aKE+2VbzuHGQD/rT1+a/X1zK0uovux10Ok0xUPnis=.sha256)

This coding session and its results serve as practice to implement the bookmarking system which will have a novel feature: It will allow you to track a URL so that you're notified if the content of that URL changes. The main use case for this is subscribing to RSS and ATOM feeds and tracking gemtext pages that are used like blog indexes.
[@Cameron Leslie](@2dtfbuH7XvPVNQvHcEIwwz89XbcobYceIQvvhpA5UZM=.ed25519) just style :-) at least with racket language, other bundled languages might treat it differently.

[@Cameron Leslie](@2dtfbuH7XvPVNQvHcEIwwz89XbcobYceIQvvhpA5UZM=.ed25519) so, don't know how familiar you are with [Racket](https://racket-lang.org) but at the top of the file there is a _language identifier_ which declares in which language the source code is. Racket ships with a dozen languages inside. In that code sample I'm using `#lang racket/base` which a subset of Racket, makes it quicker to launch that script since it doesn't need the full power of all Racket. Racket ships with languages that don't look like Racket, for example:

**Datalog:** Which is a logic programming language.

```
#lang datalog

ancestor(A, B) :- parent(A, B).
ancestor(A, B) :-
  parent(A, C), ancestor(C, B).
parent(john, douglas).
parent(bob, john).
ancestor(A, B)?
```

> Is there a core of goodness in there somewhere that’s worth saving?

The web is wonderful. I like this overcomplicated VM. It is full of amazing powers. Stop and imagine for a second, which other piece of tech is cross-platform like the web? You have clients viewing web apps on their iPads and on Amigas. It is also retrocompatible, you can load a website from 1998 without much trouble. And you can link across platforms and ages. It is an amazing stuff! The spec might be shit to implement but it is golden shit! 

Now, what I see as the problem is that the companies pushing the web forward don't share the same reality as the rest of us. FAANG are dealing with problems of a different nature that doesn't affect most players on the web. Instead of solving some of those problems in a way that everyone can participate — such as solving scalability with p2p — they solve it in a way that makes sense for their _behemoth-that-eats-PhDs_ workflow. You end up with protocols that are very hard to implement such as HTTP/2 and HTTP/3. You end up with Browser APIs that are damn hard to implement unless you're an operating system designer and a video game engineer.

In my mind what happened was that the web browsers became the space shuttle. It is fun and it takes us to the star but it is damn hard to work with and  you won't be building one in your backyard. You don't necessarily need to take a trip on a space shuttle to go buy groceries on the corner shop. FAANG want the stars and are dragging all of us into it when we actually need a safer and more powerful kickscooter. 

----

You can think of it as little boats. An enterprising person might build their own sailboat and have a ton of fun and travel many of the same seas as larger boats. Not all of them, but many. Now imagine if there was a spec saying that to be a boat you needed to be a transatlantic cruiser. All of a sudden, only few companies can build boats. Everything else is no longer a boat, right? 

----

That is what I think happened. We lost the web because we let those companies with infinitely deep pockets move the specs in the direction of their problems and not in the direction of what would make it more sustainable and easy to implement for everyone.

The way to change it is not do a _slash and burn_ but to fiddle with the user agents until they understand simpler stuff. Once the users reclaim user agents, other paths can evolve in parallel to the huge web.
Thanks friends, I'm going to check them all!

This is the [precursor](https://www.bunniestudios.com/blog/?p=5921).

> Precursor is a mobile, open source electronics platform. Similar to how a Raspberry Pi or an Arduino can be transformed into an IoT gadget with the addition of a couple breakout boards, some solder, and a bit of code, Precursor is a framework upon which you can assemble a wide variety of DIY mobile applications.
> 
> Precursor is unique in the open source electronics space in that it’s designed from the ground-up to be carried around in your pocket. It’s not just a naked circuit board with connectors hanging off at random locations: it comes fully integrated—with a rechargeable battery, a display, and a keyboard—in a sleek, 7.2 mm (quarter-inch) aluminum case.
>
> — _Source: [Introducing Precursor « bunnie's blog](https://www.bunniestudios.com/blog/?p=5921)_

And from the pre-launch page:

> Made For the Lab. Fits In Your Pocket. Does What it Says.
> 
> Precursor is an open hardware development platform for secure, mobile computation and communication. Though it accommodates a built-in display, a physical keyboard, and an internal battery, this pocket-sized device remains smaller and lighter than the average smartphone. Precursor was built for everyday use but compromises nothing as a development platform. Powered by an FPGA-hosted, soft-core System-on-Chip (SoC), it gives developers the freedom to customize nearly every aspect of the platform.
> 
> Precursor was designed from the ground up to provide security by justifying trust in an increasingly hostile world. Its transparent, minimalistic design invites inspection and mitigates supply chain attacks; its embedded cryptographic primitives simplify the implementation of computationally-intensive protocols, such as the Double Ratchet that has brought end-to-end encrypted communication into the mainstream; and its sealing primitives facilitate the creation and storage of cryptographic keys.
> 
> Despite a tightly integrated mobile form factor, Precursor also provides hooks for hardware mods. Its keyboard is a separate, I²C-provisioned PCB that opens the door to novel layouts and innovative sensors; and its battery cavity exposes GPIOs that allow developers to trade battery life for additional hardware functionality.
>
> — _Source: [Precursor | Crowd Supply](https://www.crowdsupply.com/sutajio-kosagi/precursor)_

I think this is interesting for the same people who find the #mnt-reform interesting. Bonus that this comes with an FPGA as its brain and a soft RISCV core in it. So you can have "any" CPU you want (for a finite and extremely limited definition of "any")

# ✨ Fafi Browser new features teaser ✨

![video:2020-09-23_16-43-36.mp4](&QTZLSrcviIlwKsHsx5UJCZGR7rXO/2kiuuUC+2BG8Pk=.sha256)

This is a quick sneak peek video on some new features I'm building for Fafi 0.10.

* Preferences
* Bookmarks

Fafi is primarily a #gemini browser but it knows a trick or two regarding other protocols and file formats 😸

----

The bookmarks system is quite cute. It uses a hash table to hold the bookmarks. The keys are the URLs which are duplicated in the value as well. I set it like that because it makes it easier to update a bookmark than if it was a list and I had to iterate over it to find which record I needed to update.

```lisp
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;
;;; BOOKMARKS SYSTEM
;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(define bookmarks-file (build-path data-folder "bookmarks.rktd"))

(define bookmarks (make-parameter (make-hash)))

(serializable-struct bookmark
                     (url
                      title
                      subscribe
                      favourite
                      last-checksum
                      tags
                      notes)
                     #:mutable
                     #:transparent)

(define (make-bookmark url [title ""] [subscribe #f] [favourite #f] [last-checksum 0] [tags '()] [notes ""])
  (bookmark url title subscribe favourite last-checksum tags notes))

(define (add-bookmark b)
  (let ([bs (bookmarks)])
    (hash-set! bs (bookmark-url b) b)
    (save-bookmarks)))

(define (save-bookmarks)
  (let ([s (serialize (bookmarks))])
    (with-output-to-file bookmarks-file
      (lambda () (write s))
      #:exists 'replace)))

(define (load-bookmarks)
  (let ([bs (if (file-exists? bookmarks-file)
                (with-input-from-file bookmarks-file
                  (lambda () (deserialize (read))))
                (make-hash))])
    (bookmarks bs)))
                      
```

That is the full code of the bookmark implementation.

I think you're missing the main point [@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) which is that good journalism cost a ton of money. Some of the large players in that list are American which has a much more profitable advertising revenue than those from other countries. Others are specialized and charge more. Some are from News Corp which can feed on itself and thus offload some of its costs to its sister publications and parent company. It is very different when you deal with an independent paper for example.

Everyone wants quality journalism but people don't want to pay the cost to have it made. Everyone hates advertising but don't want to pay publications enough so that they can work without advertising. We can't have it all. So it happened today and it was a great experience. James asked everyone to avoid posting about the coffees tasted for some days to give a chance to those that were not able to experience it live to enjoy it without influences. The whole event lasted about an hours and you can watch it all if you want on this [link for the Youtube recording](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=98MD900CAzg). 

#### The kit

It was really well made, I'm amazed that they shipped 17 thousand kits worldwide and it cost only 8 pounds for me to have it.

![It came in a box](&wV1Y0B1f9c0DOj+02GwwIgfswfqZXPgTcdoSaINeSu8=.sha256)
_This is the box we received._

![Kits content](&Lj/AXxljib6sn5vTgZEa6JZ9PTBi5lGGoYk7ExBHMHQ=.sha256)
_This its contents._

The kit included a cute paper griffon, a gain size sample, five unspecified coffee samples labeled A to E, a mineral supplement for distilled/ionized water. Unfortunately I couldn't source distilled or ionized water in time to use the mineral supplements. The plan is that by using that everyone would "use the same water" but I had to settle for still water from the grocery store as my tap water is a bit to hard.

#### The experience

I was delayed getting ready to the live event because I was having a pint at a local put (empty of locals and using an outdoor table) with my wife. It took me a while to hand-grind all the coffee and assemble the stuff I was going to use.

I don't need to use #python often. Maybe every three or four years, I have a sysadmin need for scripting something directly on the live server. In these cases I find Python invaluable. I never learned it properly but I can still be quite productive with python

We have a #rust based CLI tool (hack?) that converts an epub to a pwa. We use it to convert our catalog of books. It is a manual process involving JSON-based batch job description files and manual oversight. We release few books a year, so it is OK.

Someone noticed that some books were missing their PWAs on the site. My task was to identify which books were missing and convert them. For this I used a 57-lines Python script that finds the files, and generated the JSON for our epub2pwa Rust tool.

Python is so damn easy that even without knowing the language (and probably breaking all PEP8 guidelines), this was solved in just a couple hours. 20 books were found, 18 were converted. The two missing books are probably out of the epub spec.

This kind of job doesn't happen often for me, but every time it does, I remember that this battery-included language is really really good for scripting.

Went full Brazilian today and am drinking coffee from a glass. This is how they used to serve me coffee in the little bakery/snack shops we had all over town. I don't remember there being so many shops like those anymore, they either became more fancy and now have inflated prices and cater for a more wealthy middle-class; or they closed down. 

Before moving to the UK, there were five of such shops in a 5 blocks radius from my home. Four of those shops became the fancy version of old time bakeries, just one of them retains a bit of character from old times. I used to have breakfast — dark and strong filtered black coffee plus a buttered demi-baguette toast — multiple times a week. My city is smaller than Rio, and in those bakeries they did serve us ceramic mugs but, when I was still working in downtown Rio, with all the fast and crazy morning commuters that make Londoners feel lazy and peaceful, the bakeries couldn't serve us mugs. Clients would come and go too fast, it felt like a F1 pitstop: "drink in two gulps, burn your throat, eat in two bites, choke, run to your job". The solution was serving coffee using common glass, the kind that is equally used for coffee, beer, or cachaça (a large cachaça, not the tiny coward cup).

![image.png](&9xG3RUOnjleytsiZnFuP62kOJ4hyPAlv8tBTveDVlMQ=.sha256)
_those shops used to look like this._

![image.png](&YahUKw/D4m2K8O/uodVh0tCchXcKHeExlqFCT0SOcQo=.sha256)
_This is the one I used to have breakfast, they had a restoration and became fancier._

Rio and Niterói used to have so many cafés like that. They are not like coffee shops like we have here in the UK, they are an hybrid between coffee shops, bakeries, snack bar, pub, and restaurant. Do you want to have breakfast? Lunch? A beer? Buy a birthday cake? A cocktail? They serve it all. I miss those places.

Now, for those that read this far, a bit of a treat. This is the prettiest coffee shop (actually they call themselves a confeitaria, which I guess makes them a _patisserie_) in Rio. It is called Confeitaria Colombo.

![image.png](&YecHhnJBErS2mGg/OMP5KovUYTDi1BwadaLI+VbYS94=.sha256)

[@Alex](@ujT9G7p4h1zeFiq7qX79eAQDyL2pTo0rLgIA7iA4VIY=.ed25519) French presses changed how I drink coffee. Before having one, I'd always drink coffee in shops (I just posted about it in #showmeyourcoffee). It is not that I didn't had a coffee maker at home, or that I was not aware of French presses, for I remember them from some fuzzy memory of my youth. I think it is because my parents are espresso people, so I was not into coffee at home. It was when we got older and some of my friends started opening coffee shops, that I had my first real experience with different brewing methods and fell in love with the French press (and the clever, and the aeropress, and the v60...)

Back in Niterói (my original city), you can go to a coffee shop, even a Starbucks, and order a French press. They'll just prepare it, and serve a tray with the cups and the press. We'd just sit there in a group of three or four and order a 1-liter French press. I was surprised that I can't do that here in London.

This led me to owning multiple presses (two at home; two at work), and having a bunch of gear here in the UK at home. I currently have two presses (a small and a large), an aeropress, and a v60. I'm still wondering if I should get a clever, I really liked them.

I really believe that now that you own your own press and can experiment with coffee at home, that you'll enjoy coffee much more than you did.

Working on Little Webby Press all day today. I'm refactoring to switch from _Bootstrap_ to _Tailwind CSS_. I'm much more comfortable with _Bootstrap_ and other toolkits that are similar to it, mostly because they take you by the hand and offer a ton of pre-made components. On the opposite end of the spectrum, _Tailwind CSS_ offers a ton of tooling and features but it is not big on pre-made components. Using it feels like going back to my days at the uni in the _Desktop Publishing_ class, and to be honest I like that. It will take me longer to build the UI but in the end I think the project will be better.

I'm also refactoring the code. The previous proof-of-concept was basically a waterfall function that built everything. It worked but it makes it a lot harder to maintain and evolve. If I want people to contribute to this project, I need to adhere to better standards.

This is my setup for working today. Connected to the main monitor is my _Surface Pro X_ running _Windows 10_, I'm using it to work on #littlewebbypress. 

Next to the monitor is a _Thinkpad x230_ running [Haiku OS](https://haiku-os.org) which is my favourite Desktop operating system (that is still alive). On its screen you can glimpse at [QuiteRSS](https://quiterss.org/) which is a feed reader that was ported. It doesn't feel quite native, much like the other QT-based ports, but it is better to have ported software than not having any software. 

On my really large _Thermo_ there is _less-than-a-liter_ of filtered black #coffee made with a _Hario v60_. I made a liter earlier today and I've been drinking it as I work. Later in the day I'll switch to tea or chai. 

The confusion happening inside that pot next to the thinkpad is part of my collection of pens. I need a larger pot or another case to store the ones I don't use much. My _Sakura Gelly Rolls_ are not seeing much use and they occupy 2/3rds of that pot. On the photo you can see part of my favourite fountain pen, it is the _TWSBI Eco_, and you can see its bright yellow cap. Next to it and not able to actually fit in the tight cup is my latest pen, a _Pilot Prera_ with an Italic nib, I'm still not sure that as a left-handed human with terrible handwriting that I'll be able to use it effectively. I'm considering buying some cursive practice notebooks for adults, it is time I up my game.

My favourite fox mug is also in the picture.

Now, it is time for you to #showmeyoursetup

I've been using [Haiku OS](https://haiku-os.org) more and more these days. It feels peaceful, it feels like going back home. I mentioned in [this post about my working setup for the day](%NpR+1IauHXUZUrCFDIP1EHnT93J+BFQiPi997KmWNrM=.sha256) that I'm using a ported app to read feeds and that got me thinking about application development and Haiku.

Many people here probably never experienced that amazing operating system. Many are only familiar with the big three — Windows, macOS, Linux — and never used a different system. I think some here might love Haiku and I recommend installing it in a VM and playing around, but that is not the main reason for this post.

What I want to say is that is has become much easier to port software to Haiku now that is has a working Qt port. If you know your C++ and Qt, you can help port or develop apps for the system. For those that don't want to learn _Be API_ due to it being applicable just on a single niche operating system, Qt is a way to develop some FOSS apps that will benefit many systems.

Why not take Haiku for a spin? Why not play with developing for it? :D

_PS: I'm considering making a video channel like the "Serenity OS" channel. I'd use that channel to stream me learning _Be API_ and building little apps. I haven't programmed anything for Haiku since 2004 and forgot most of it._

# PARTY TIME ✨ 🍰 

It is time for celebration, for the first time since I started programming _Little Webby Press_, a book generated by the tool passed the validation from [epubcheck](https://github.com/w3c/epubcheck) without any warnings or error.

Just a quick video to show some unique UX and features of Haiku. 

* Haiku applications are heavily multithreaded. All native apps will have multiple threads just by using the Be API.
* An application is a _team of threads_.
* You have fine grained control over priority and thread usage from the GUI. There is no need to fall back to a terminal.

![video:bug.mp4](&UxUOuZDmg/mEdUPZU4Nm7zojSkl5WEMIFe0C8C2RjWA=.sha256)

In this video, I launch QuiteRSS which is a Linux Qt4 port. I use the [ProcessController (user guide link)](https://www.haiku-os.org/docs/userguide/en/desktop-applets/processcontroller.html) applet to check on memory usage, list threads, and then kill the app.

This app bugged out on me today and it started displaying rendering artifacts inside its view. I killed it. That is when I realized that many people here have not been exposed to this kind of UX. It is as easy as the Task Manager on Windows but as powerful as Linux command line tools. You can even change thread priority per thread using the GUI.

Heck, you can even enable and disable CPUs cores from the Process Controller.

![image.png](&kEvoasQbQ5GD3N0ElncsOUknBZfSshLBIwrQESVH6Nw=.sha256)

## SSB Post Summary 1 (Sept 3 - 9)

Some general guidelines:  
Posts shared here will be original, community-made content. Images will be linked but not embedded to keep the newsletter easily scrollable. I use the pronouns in profile descriptions, otherwise they/them. If I use the wrong pronouns, let me know! I'll update it in future issues and issue a correction statement if you want.

I have read all posts linked here, but not necessarily their parent threads or links within posts, so click at your own risk.

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Thanks for reading the first issue, everyone! Feel free to talk to me about it in the comments, DMs, or even by DMing my main account, [@romeo](@LrIL+UAvV+msJFiCxKZMJHCDASB8ekaSefbH8qdEwKI=.ed25519). If you want to help contribute, let me know! If you really want something in here but it doesn't fit under the general guidelines, I'll make a section like "Community Submissions" or similar. So don't be shy! On a more personal note, I've found the biggest challenge so far is trying to actually read what I scroll through instead of only skimming to see if it would belong in the SPS (Scuttlebutt Post Summary). It definitely takes a level of mindfulness to consume the content and make that decision simultaneously. Despite that, I think I'm doing well! If the community got huge I would need help with running SPS, but at its current size and with what I can see of it, it takes about a half hour in the morning and evening to catch up and write entries for posts I want to include. And for me, that's manageable! Thanks again for reading, everyone, and if you don't leave feedback, I'll see you in about a week!

I'm noticing it's hard to fit posts into nice week-shaped boxes due to ssb being a long-term type of platform. You'll see this week, and in the future, a lot of "Discussion continues..." type posts. I figure as long as there's still new info being added, it's worth another click. And typically you'll be able to tell it's a repeat link by the "Discussion continues", if you don't want to see it again. This week's summary is about an hour late, oops. I was playing Fall Guys to win a skin that looked like Godzilla for [@zaz](@v93CLJG6v9Y8A5yCKrFYfgc03FyqiN0wFN5cCX7jiV0=.ed25519). Hope everyone is doing well, and I'll see you all next week :)

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Happy October! Special section under art for inktober. I've heard the dude is trying to be a jerk about copyright and stuff but he can't catch me on here, so I will be calling it inktober as a catch-all for October month-long drawing challenges. Related, this is the first issue to have one of my posts in it! I debated myself on putting it in but I figured since I put every other inktober in I should put mine too.
This one is a little late since I've been super busy all of a sudden with school. Sorry in advance if I missed something news-worthy - I put together most of this in the past hour. Still found time tho! See y'all next week :)

## SSB Post Summary
Welcome to the sixth edition of SSB Post Summary! Expect these to be roughly every seven days, but not necessarily always on Thursday. To submit a post to the newsletter, dm this account, @ it, or use the #this hashtag.

A few reminders:
- I use the pronouns in profile descriptions, otherwise they/them. If I use the wrong pronouns, let me know! I'll update it in future issues and issue a correction statement if you want.
- I have read all posts linked here, but not necessarily their parent threads or links within posts, so click at your own risk.

### Art

[Thread](%fnc5Rxd2OxinqIOqQsh8oeofYmciWChrqLswK6RDLYw=.sha256) about P2P and SSB

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Been thinking about this newsletter thing. Thought for a little bit about making a third account to follow everyone who could post something newsworthy. I've decided that this newsletter is not going to try to sum up the entire scuttleverse. This is heavily biased by my personal views and the people I choose to follow, and I'm okay with that. If you think I should put stuff in that I don't or vice versa, talk to me! If I don't change my mind, start your own post summary. I would love to see more of these reflecting other people's personal choices in what qualifies as newsworthy.
These have been late lately, I've been busy with school. It happens. I'm going to try not to miss a week completely because I know I would never start up again.

I finally got this account set up! First news post will drop tonight at midnight EST (about 2.5 hours from now), covering Sept 3 - 9. If you have last-minute posts you want to see in it, send them here or to [@romeo](@LrIL+UAvV+msJFiCxKZMJHCDASB8ekaSefbH8qdEwKI=.ed25519) (my main)!

Also, I will only be following [@romeo](@LrIL+UAvV+msJFiCxKZMJHCDASB8ekaSefbH8qdEwKI=.ed25519) from this account. No hard feelings, I just don't want anyone to feel left out. I gather news from my main account, so no worries about this account missing important posts.

## SSB Post Summary 1 (Sept 3 - 9)
Welcome to the first edition of SSB Post Summary! Expect these to be roughly every seven days, but not necessarily always on Thursday. To submit a post to the newsletter, dm this account, @ it, or use the #this hashtag.

Some general guidelines:  
Posts shared here will be original, community-made content. Images will be linked but not embedded to keep the newsletter easily scrollable. I use the pronouns in profile descriptions, otherwise they/them. If I use the wrong pronouns, let me know! I'll update it in future issues and issue a correction statement if you want.

I have read all posts linked here, but not necessarily their parent threads or links within posts, so click at your own risk.

### Art
Sept 3: [@dinoworm](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519) and [@matt](@FbGoHeEcePDG3Evemrc+hm+S77cXKf8BRQgkYinJggg=.ed25519) linked some [music](%hKf7QjZqDzczfAkD8xe9MWBlErm3The2+f8OZPoolBM=.sha256) they made with feedhack over the past few months

Sept 3: [@hoodownr](@YND2Cb9uk3ZdFyzXpaXDH5HZ9udu+qjg4MhNcynK2RE=.ed25519) shared one of their [drawings](%y6yESDEzlKHp2C7opRo0zOfetf/kmt+v/S5D98CLA84=.sha256)

Sept 4: [@David Gómez](@b0e9vLp8gLDnO2EZY90IpQ2s2srEm4RYYr7VbRkLmQw=.ed25519) took pictures of [the sunset in Istanbul](%S0CU7XkA707T0ITsn66M8Uxam0NNc2ss0+TZ4mgZdoc=.sha256)

Sept 4: [@Daan](@MRiJ+CvDnD9ZjqunY1oy6tsk0IdbMDC4Q3tTC8riS3s=.ed25519) took a picture of [the Grand Tête de l’Obiou](%HX3watjwe1LcC9HhJpAQMH0GJwI3vH/xSAngRXUYatk=.sha256)

Sept 4: [@skyebend](@F/Lw6U9khCl8f/BrfYbSnsd1jMFqK+9otnyKBwfp9Es=.ed25519) shared a picture of [the moon](%2zewxTHCPnITfVRtynRl2vFiggYLg5lBEmQxf36xcRs=.sha256)

Sept 4: [@bobhaugen](@iL6NzQoOLFP18pCpprkbY80DMtiG4JFFtVSVUaoGsOQ=.ed25519) has been working on a [blog](%VstQyqmEAmiKiHITNd5FuXF/xVEQjXqWNAyA7WuWJ2I=.sha256)

Sept 6: [@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519) tried out [drawing with a brush pen](%PZBL7k6rGh5BRDLE+FwZgfmCBc/A15qwglR8SepSgmw=.sha256)

Sept 6: [@Powersource](@WuIiSwHyJS9v8EZ8RUL8Jgft9GSOPd02EvAaT+3U8oM=.ed25519) took a picture of [Stockholm](%39CjmbMt/UUtUQy6XYeXIg1NB2g28tP/l+S7k0uiWDk=.sha256) (CW for police and injury in the picture directly below this one)

Sept 7: [@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) shared some [pictures from a hike](%+QKHapzR/lz7F/KLn5JeGWXEjw4mvGWTBgQh3qBuxHs=.sha256)

(more to follow in replies - I hit the post size limit)

### Food and Gardening
Sept 3: [@cel](@lOUVT+Phkvai9a/cCS/RKo+S9hnPAQdVixms/7ldpPA=.ed25519) showed us some [home grown tomatoes](%G2Qrxihu+6k5h6qOVCHLuCplqXbPg9xqLWl4Sie+urY=.sha256)

Sept 4: [@Netscape Navigator](@z2M8msI2EUubNHnrEJncglDIy2/SUd+36jCyJnfeiHk=.ed25519) made [mofongo](%ItvBVqwGY0Uh66ORiJYdXTZf8Vflrtq9rH0pB1ojzMs=.sha256). CW: this post might have a picture with a bottle of alcohol in the background - I can't tell but stay safe if alcohol is a trigger.

Sept 5: [@amandabee](@TpugRyODinGusTfOyYhVrz9rmNsR3K0F1jucrSZv0HI=.ed25519) made [apple cider](%HVY7KDT1yixW242E+p5qlwlO2xN1vPMTECYe6c9BOQM=.sha256)

### Tech
Sept 3: [@Luandro](@2RNGJafZtMHzd76gyvqH6EJiK7kBnXeak5mBWzoO/iU=.ed25519) shared the [latest updates](%c+yMaH7gYXWvdXauQVTCvl3YX97G62TD+yr6PtQBXbE=.sha256) on their [mesh networking project](%hMC/Ix/mnDvk0KYGcvXGo/Kt8UuegWYz6vB91RyhIKQ=.sha256) between villages in Brazilian territory

Sept 4: [@Cameron Leslie](@2dtfbuH7XvPVNQvHcEIwwz89XbcobYceIQvvhpA5UZM=.ed25519) is making [comic writing software](%EQy/DkNSM1zPMiMm3p1V0cH/ZWxtIltNiOaqtayOnHc=.sha256) with a friend

Sept 5: [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) [updated Manyverse](%R9xO6YW+xwyL5n9c2NtOJvdVCyxBUJceLk1t91v4c2w=.sha256)

Sept 8: [@SoapDog](@qv10rF4IsmxRZb7g5ekJ33EakYBpdrmV/vtP1ij5BS4=.ed25519) wrote about how they [automate tasks](%8QVjysHt9NWe79pED5N8IAfI8Pq/Ni8QfSLwC8rNmLg=.sha256)

Sept 9: [@arj](@6CAxOI3f+LUOVrbAl0IemqiS7ATpQvr9Mdw9LC4+Uv0=.ed25519) is working on [SSB from a browser](%mlWGJI2JfRiyI308kdCUvwyS4t5P9Ogx+n4A2+I+xyk=.sha256)

### SSB Community and Meta
Sept 3: [@Zonerunner](@njX70qj68Z1z51eqtr2VjT3YUrokAsU2ZNAFWkqYFME=.ed25519) gave us a [tool](%0ES1ZU2nWLncYuYpwHm7X74dLROP1U3wz6vjWb9vbTE=.sha256) for communicating tone through text

Sept 5: [@lxoliva](@hhknMruxen2tXWeQYkpKlFsm09ye5R9TrYQyKsM47kU=.ed25519) started/contributed to [a conversation](%rVyCds6YsJu6XGfYgF8P5+qyqJ1zrtUyIR5tXXIxzd4=.sha256) about peer pressure, blocking, and general community health

Sept 9: [@inoas](%hkqlPKzVixRFIcKja9Q6ojH9Nr53/il+9CSy7IQj7Sc=.sha256) suggested a [language tag for ssb posts](%hkqlPKzVixRFIcKja9Q6ojH9Nr53/il+9CSy7IQj7Sc=.sha256)

(still a little more)

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Thanks for reading the first issue, everyone! Feel free to talk to me about it in the comments, DMs, or even by DMing my main account, [@romeo](@LrIL+UAvV+msJFiCxKZMJHCDASB8ekaSefbH8qdEwKI=.ed25519). If you want to help contribute, let me know! If you really want something in here but it doesn't fit under the general guidelines, I'll make a section like "Community Submissions" or similar. So don't be shy! On a more personal note, I've found the biggest challenge so far is trying to actually read what I scroll through instead of only skimming to see if it would belong in the SPS (Scuttlebutt Post Summary). It definitely takes a level of mindfulness to consume the content and make that decision simultaneously. Despite that, I think I'm doing well! If the community got huge I would need help with running SPS, but at its current size and with what I can see of it, it takes about a half hour in the morning and evening to catch up and write entries for posts I want to include. And for me, that's manageable! Thanks again for reading, everyone, and if you don't leave feedback, I'll see you in about a week!

## SSB Post Summary
Welcome to the second edition of SSB Post Summary! Expect these to be roughly every seven days, but not necessarily always on Thursday. To submit a post to the newsletter, dm this account, @ it, or use the #this hashtag.

### Letter from the Author/Editor
I'm noticing it's hard to fit posts into nice week-shaped boxes due to ssb being a long-term type of platform. You'll see this week, and in the future, a lot of "Discussion continues..." type posts. I figure as long as there's still new info being added, it's worth another click. And typically you'll be able to tell it's a repeat link by the "Discussion continues", if you don't want to see it again. This week's summary is about an hour late, oops. I was playing Fall Guys to win a skin that looked like Godzilla for [@zaz](@v93CLJG6v9Y8A5yCKrFYfgc03FyqiN0wFN5cCX7jiV0=.ed25519). Hope everyone is doing well, and I'll see you all next week :)

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Happy October! Special section under art for inktober. I've heard the dude is trying to be a jerk about copyright and stuff but he can't catch me on here, so I will be calling it inktober as a catch-all for October month-long drawing challenges. Related, this is the first issue to have one of my posts in it! I debated myself on putting it in but I figured since I put every other inktober in I should put mine too.
This one is a little late since I've been super busy all of a sudden with school. Sorry in advance if I missed something news-worthy - I put together most of this in the past hour. Still found time tho! See y'all next week :)

[Thread](%fnc5Rxd2OxinqIOqQsh8oeofYmciWChrqLswK6RDLYw=.sha256) about P2P and SSB

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Been thinking about this newsletter thing. Thought for a little bit about making a third account to follow everyone who could post something newsworthy. I've decided that this newsletter is not going to try to sum up the entire scuttleverse. This is heavily biased by my personal views and the people I choose to follow, and I'm okay with that. If you think I should put stuff in that I don't or vice versa, talk to me! If I don't change my mind, start your own post summary. I would love to see more of these reflecting other people's personal choices in what qualifies as newsworthy.
These have been late lately, I've been busy with school. It happens. I'm going to try not to miss a week completely because I know I would never start up again.

‪When the little not-so-little person catches up in shoe size. And starts taking over your sneaker selection. Enjoy those 25 year anniversary Nike Air Max 90 "Cork’s", Sumster!

![planetary attachment no.1](&R0eU3v2xK+SnryA36EO0ZAQLVZcuFbghWzK5AtdS/MM=.sha256)
There’s been a shortage of seeds out here. Sanne (my wife) has quite the selection too. You both should do a seed swap. Her allotment adventures at http://instagram.com/sowandgrowsanne

Awoke to find ‘Gone’, a poem by my little person, left on the breakfast table. This a little after she read Greta Thunberg’s - ‘No One Is Too Small To Make A Difference’.

![planetary attachment no.1](&926P/+Hesnd9jaXPpvHwZ571jJajZf9FKaFhh9TFjmc=.sha256)
![planetary attachment no.2](&bu1RZ3GttKg3LB7FEYSN4zUJGxtPpXxFhOhFux3dKbI=.sha256)

A year and a bit ago, Stefan and I talked long tail creators. Which led to us proposing Grant For The Web, a $100M fund to boost open, fair, and inclusive standards and innovation in Web Monetization. Soon after, Mozilla and Creative Commons announced their support. And now, we've opened up the first (of many) call-for-proposals. https://www.grantfortheweb.org/post/announcing-first-public-call-for-proposals

The Five [Polly, Annie, Eli(s)zabeth, Catherine (Kate) and Mary-Jane] tells the stories of daughters, wives, mothers, sisters and lovers. They were women. They were human beings. This has been extremely well researched by Hallie Rubenhold. Recommended. #books #jacktheripper

![planetary attachment no.1](&FXhzosvd06pb/srYULwYZ9a2pFwdgiM9DfgFk4EELQQ=.sha256)

Wall and Piece - Banksy #books #streetart

![planetary attachment no.1](&qvl8vXiAJj8BfH/TeOlJq6MRW7GHpdxX2WMOlUpbqIk=.sha256)

Whilst I’ve watched a silent movie before - I don’t recall ever reading a silent graphic novel. The illustrations are wonderful and mesmerising and have made my imaginations go wild. And as a immigrant myself, this ode to every migrant, every refugee, every displaced person, and it’s tribute to all those who have made the journey, resonates. #books 

![planetary attachment no.1](&hVeabcIo+n+hqlkTsL0iNukQSeyj99npUUtK2HPFzss=.sha256)
![planetary attachment no.1](&Ob/q8sb2J1jSCsOrGacwZm1gswwdHI1+BE9mQX/r89U=.sha256)

National Heroes Service 

![planetary attachment no.1](&BTKfGkY5PmzznW/TYGN6MJfiji/c6snOnwU6+GxD9NY=.sha256)
![planetary attachment no.1](&gnnWnSXoBQvUQKbLT2PWJuI25V90PgkspkmopfnA7Oo=.sha256)
![planetary attachment no.1](&gnnWnSXoBQvUQKbLT2PWJuI25V90PgkspkmopfnA7Oo=.sha256)
![planetary attachment no.1](&gnnWnSXoBQvUQKbLT2PWJuI25V90PgkspkmopfnA7Oo=.sha256)

Squaring up to the investigable ‘No Filter’ - a totally instagrammable story by Sarah Frier. From ‘Normal’ to ‘X-Pro II’ to ‘Rise’ to my personal favourite, ‘Lo-Fi’. The transformation from ‘Burbn’ to ‘Scotch’ bypassing ‘Whsky’ to ‘Codename’ and finally to Instagram, thereby combining the words instant and telegram. Here’s that multi billion dollar Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger  journey. 

ps. if you’re inclined to keep up with my non-influencer-level filtered squares of Streetart to Family to Travel, do check out: https://lnkd.in/dB6k2je

content.title: movement + meditation
content.description:
Free contemplative yoga + simple meditation for one hour every Friday morning at [Woodbine.nyc](http://woodbine.nyc). The intention of this class is to address many of the body and mind patterns we fall into by accident, especially working on computers or phones: hunched shoulders, curled spines, achy hips and constantly-chattering thought spirals. 

We will be standing and sitting in chairs, but will not go on the floor, so you do not need to bring a yoga mat. Wear anything you find comfortable bending over in. Tea will be provided. <3
