- **10x** [Watherproof cases](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1199130696-10-caixas-proteco-organizadoras-cftv-de-sobrepor-_JM) - **R$55,00** (11 USD)
- **2x** [5W 5V solar charger](https://www.neosolar.com.br/loja/carregador-solar-portatil-5w-com-usb-neosolar.html) - **R$285,00** (54 USD)
- **2x** [10W solar panel](https://www.neosolar.com.br/loja/painel-solar-fotovoltaico-10w-sinosola-sa10-36p.html) - **R$225,00** (43 USD)

### From China (not counting on them to arrive in time)
- **2x** [Rak4600 boards](https://aliexpress.com/item/4000344205753.html) - **65.25 USD**
- **7x** [5dbi 916Mhz moxon antennas](https://aliexpress.com/item/4001346497567.html) - **70.00 USD**
- **1x** [nanovna v2 vector analizer](https://aliexpress.com/item/4000390703223.html) - **63.10 USD**

So far totaling **740,35 USD**. It's probably twice the cost people in any other part of the world would pay ( 🇧🇷 highest import taxes in the world), but it's still very cheap compared to any other connectivity solution that I know of (HF Radio, GSM, 5Ghz). There are still small parts that are missing like cables, bolts, etc, and of course the poles to set the LoRa kits, which we'll be using wood or bamboo extracted close to the sites.

There's a strike of the national delivery service going on, so some items will probably be delayed. Expecting to start building a first prototype and testing it by the end of September, and trying to organize a trip to the territory by mid October. Wish us luck 🤞

## Quick update

Went to town to test if I could get signal on the possible areas pointed out by the simulation on [Test 1](%c+yMaH7gYXWvdXauQVTCvl3YX97G62TD+yr6PtQBXbE=.sha256), but got none within the urban area. I'm guessing it's because there are too many buildings, maybe in a higher place...

That concludes the first test. Positively surprised by the outcome.

👏 👏 👏 [@Rômulo Alves](@xr/Q/zqaEwmmd4wg8xRU1TrMLQhc9qBqNCioCqmv1vQ=.ed25519)!

Very awaited feature. I hope to collaborate in adding audio recording.
😢 What happened? His books have had a big influence on my personal development.

[@sam_uk](@s5nSo+j0D+tTklVi1kZqDsgEV0mLtums7UgyGAClD/0=.ed25519)

> I’d avoid a exposed USB, I think it will rust within 6-12 months.

My plan so far has been to cover it with silicon and then with epoxy resin, just to make sure. Any better ideas are really welcome :)

> I don’t know if you’ve come across Rachel/ World possible?

I'm never really tested it, but heard a lot about Rachel. At #coolab we've been slowly writing scripts for our a custom pi-server, to fit the needs of the communities we interact with. In the [community-portal app](https://moinho.network) I've added a space for "Apps", which doesn't have much yet. The list u have there is really great, I'll definitely include some of those apps. Thanks for sharing.

--------------
This is incredible resource [@emile](@2YVYXQclEJHVzCON5dsLRwf65b2S6HnvxpGS8/LwjwY=.ed25519) 🙏 

 [Beyond Line-of-Sight UHF Digital Communications with the LoRa Spread Spectrum Waveform.pdf](&0GrbSXzQqexXOCEybe5p9OMzRc0bAGEYjLAkvBGWi+U=.sha256)

Bits I found relevant:
- troposcatter allows for communications up to about 700km (using LoRa), with diffraction being limited to even shorter distances
-  they require a substantial link budget that requires high receive sensitivity, high transmit power, and high antenna gain
- diffraction is generally useful for shorter distance BLoS
- at longer distances, troposcatter provides BLoS propagation by scattering radio waves off irregularities in density and moisture in the upper troposphere. Troposcatter is a reliable communication method, but its effectiveness does vary based on weather conditions and can suffer from fast fading issues
- total path loss is at least 160-170dB for troposcatter communications
-  the 915MHz product and the 433MHz product align with the 70cm and 33cm amateur bands respectively.
-  the 433MHz product was used mainly to leverage the abundance of 70cm amateur radio
equipment, including low-cost antennas and power amplifiers; and feedline losses are lower on
lower frequencies
- [Halo antenna on the cheap](http://www.kr1st.com/70cmstack.htm)
- [Yagi antenna on the cheap](http://wa5vjb.com/yagi-pdf/cheapyagi.pdf)
- [LoRa airtime calculator](https://www.loratools.nl/#/airtime)

For the specific case of the Krahô territory, in the savanna, the geography and vegetation are blessings, so having a node at the center enables communication in most parts of the territory. But troposcatter is very relevant for the Amazon region. The amplifier might be the trick, as they seem to be a bit pricey and doing a quick search I can't even seem to find one in Brazil.

content.text:
*Re-posting from ["meshtastic to connect isolate villages"](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/meshtastic-to-connect-isolated-villages) thread*
# Test 1

Just did a test, placing a T-Beam on top of the hill where the main #librerouter node in #moinho-mesh sits.

![lora_torre_moinho_teste1.jpg](&KADPrUXxB09s7D30ZtGXFo5GpJOzHEr7zvrEYcEa33Q=.sha256)

The green area is the expected reach using the simulation. Unfortunately I didn't have the map with me to check exactly where to get the best signal in the nearby town (Alto Paraíso de Goiás), so I drove to the wrong places to test. The green and red lines are where I drove and got signal (green 💚 ) or not (red 🔴 )

But I was very surprised with these results, I was expecting to climb a hill to get a message through, but from inside the car messages were being sent no problem (using the maximum range/lowest speed settings). Within #moinho I got a connection everywhere.

# Star network

Based on the simulation for the Krahô territory I've decided to change strategies, and go for the best spot on the whole territory, making possible for all villages to connect. The trick here is to either have a really good omni:

![lora_kraho_central_nodes_omni.jpg](&TJC7z0l/OJlKDh1LlsokyrmQLEvq5RUBcGRdbJsQR14=.sha256)

Or place two nodes at the 435m high hill, each one with a yagi, which might be more guarateed to work, but would require placing more nodes at the center in case villages in the other directions want join the network:

![lora_kraho_central_nodes_yagi.jpg](&AtCn4UM5WsnzaNds/a5ErkNWAnXtY/AlmcxCqrOMJ+w=.sha256)

Probably worth testing the two options, by first placing nodes at the villages, then going up the hill and testing omni and yagis.

Almost decided on the kit I'll be going for, based on **simplicity** (for less points of failure), **price** and national **availability**.

- **5x** [5W pannel with 5V USB](https://www.neosolar.com.br/loja/carregador-solar-portatil-5w-com-usb-neosolar.html) - **R$ 110,00** (22.55 USD each)
- **5x** [TTGO LoRa](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1183694492-modulo-wifi-esp32-com-suporte-de-bateria-gps-e-lora-915mhz-_JM) - **R$ 220,00** (41.00 USD each)
- **1x** [Omni antenna](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-905740373-antena-omni-veicular-15-dbi-824-2600-mhz-_JM) (still not ideal, but only one I could find) - **R$ 325,00** (61.00 USD)
- **2x** [Yagi antenas](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1516947026-antena-externa-para-celular-18-dbi-806-a-960-mhz-_JM) (806-960mhz) - **R$ 107,00** (20.00 USD each)
- **5 meters of** [copper tubing](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1506079214-cano-cobre-38-para-tubulaco-gas-glp-ar-condicionado-split-_JM) (to test making antennas) - **R$ 127,00** (24.00 USD)
#rede-moinho

# The first experiment

I've been in touch with our Krahô collaborator and he's really excited for the experiment. He has confirmed support from the community for lodging and food during my stay. Besides doing this experiment I'm hoping to introduce them to tools such as #mapeo, #ahau, #manyverse, #huiom and the #librerouter, which might be of use to them.

I've been thinking on driving there during the first two weeks of October. But until then, there are still tests to do, and an equipment list to define and buy. I'll be using my own savings, but hope to crowd-fund it back later on.

This is a first draft of the mesh plan we'll be attempting at their territory.

![link_LORA_manuelalves_serragrande.jpg](&SE34VdPdHUa4R22MCYNQ74Ro1Gm4xXJJz5h4KtDIVzo=.sha256)
*A mesh plan using 5 repeater nodes to bridge 2 villages that are 43.2Km away*

I've started to interact with the Meshtastic community thru this topic on their discourse channel: [Meshtastic to connect isolated villages](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/meshtastic-to-connect-isolated-villages)

They've been giving me good tips on antennas, solar setups and on how realistic such a mesh is. Good tips include using panel with 5V output in order connect it directly to the board to use less parts and have as few failure points as possible and using DIY omni antennas for the repeaters (looking at [this tutorial](https://youtu.be/1_1LxuOngHs)).

Here's the equipment list so far:
- [5x Heltec LoRa boards](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1645061816-5-x-placa-lora-esp32-display-oled-wifi-bluetooth-_JM)
- [5x 5W 5v panels with USB](https://www.neosolar.com.br/loja/carregador-solar-portatil-5w-com-usb-neosolar.html)
- [5x 2200mah 18650 batteries](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1180892186-bateria-18650-samsung-22p-original-2200mah-kit-4-_JM)
- [5x 18650 battery cases](https://produto.mercadolivre.com.br/MLB-1210664880-kit-5-case-suporte-bateria-18650-para-1-bateria-37v-_JM)
- Copper for making DIY antennas (haven't found the ideal material for this yet)

All these are available here in Brasil. I'll be buying Moxon antennas and Rak4600 boards from Aliexpress, but won't be counting on them for this as things from China usually takes months to arrive (if they do).

## Test 1

Been learning to use an amazing tool for simulating radio coverage: [https://www.ve2dbe.com/rmonline_s.asp](https://www.ve2dbe.com/rmonline_s.asp)

Got a few of the settings from [this thread](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/how-to-fill-in-coverage-details-on-ve2dbe-com), but still feel it's not exactly right. Any tips are welcome.

This is the test I'll be attempting in the next few days, communicating between the two T-Beams over 7,44Km using the Meshtastic app.

![lora_moinho_conecta_link.jpg](&jB5rcl5XtnsSyLtEUJf3wp6WRJqCh3UIN9YCxlMp8Bw=.sha256)
*Map with the expected coverage of a LoRa node placed where our #moinho-mesh hill node is*

Yea, also gave consent. Interesting, didn't know the actual feed was bundled. I've authorized the viewer to display my feed, which for me is a great way to share the stuff I'm doing to the outside world, so see no harm in letting Planetary use it.

- **On the  Rak4600**: That looks like a great board. The existing nrf52dk target in meshtastic is almost exactly the same, so I bet adding it will not be too hard. I’m happy to help with questions. [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/25-low-power-dev-board-with-solar-rak4600/410/7?u=luandro)

- It sounds like there are a couple of folks working on getting a NRF52 and/or sx1262 boards out. As soon as something like that exists I bet that will be the ideal repeater node (because super low power draw and better radio performance). [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/headless-base-station-repeater/363/2?u=luandro)

- **Global messaging support** (not really about the NRF52, but related to integrating SSB+LoRa): the appeal adding an optional internet gateway is so “whenever some member of your mesh happens to connect to the internet, it will magically send/receive messages to/from any internet user”. [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/proposal-for-global-messaging-support/455/31?u=luandro)

Ok, my internet let me do some real research now. What I found about NRF52:

- On **Ultra Low Power Nodes**: This board should be able to do exactly what you describe even without having the mesh sleep (because the nrf52 and the sx1262 have absurdly low power draws while in receive mode). According to my spreadsheet his board should be able to run indefinitely as a “router” with a quite small solar cell. So you could place one of these devices (discreetly) in a tree that has good line of sight for a region and it would happily route packets for that whole area (using just a tiny solar cell). [Source](https://meshtastic.discourse.group/t/ultra-low-power-nodes/218/2?u=luandro)

- [Meshtastic airtime and current draws spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ft1bS3iXqFKU8SApU8ZLTq9r7QQEGESYnVgdtvdT67k/edit#gid=1182643433)

[@sam_uk](@s5nSo+j0D+tTklVi1kZqDsgEV0mLtums7UgyGAClD/0=.ed25519) it's always a trade-off huh? I guess we'd need to do more testing to really find out the sweet spot we should be aiming for.

I feel Disaster Radio is more aligned with the aim here, but Meshtastic does seem to have a lot of momentum, and an active community behind.

Been doing some research on the NRF52, but didn't really understand it's advantage. Is it the power efficiency? Can it run with less battery/solar power?

QMesh is exactly what I'm aiming for in the future, thanks for sharing 👍

Wow [@Nico Pace](@2AWm36HvcuOOcYeNgGgoybKXcMZx+COIf4/aAxJwnVI=.ed25519), Code 2 looks really promising. And it seems there has been [some work on getting it to work with micro-controllers](https://github.com/blanu/codec2-arduino). Thanks for the great tip 👍 

Really feel this is moving, thanks everyone :)

🙏 Thank you very much [@juul](@22YV3HX/BGClXH49ZebkcepqRpj7a9f5s0ddwhDSfxk=.ed25519). That's definitely sounds amazing. Excited for a chat!

I'm definitely a huge fan of Mapeo. Have chatted with [@Kira](@C3iYh/12sO1uvKq1KcZXLFxSySzxOkHxXN8rtNB5MGA=.ed25519) in person about it, and always following the work she and [@karissa](@hCDeKTwEhhhNXtg00adkMDi+tx6qrRApFFj49QBM3lY=.ed25519) have been doing.

I'm thinking on low bandwidth as an advantage in such situations. That's because we really don't want to affect peoples ways of lives with high-bandwidth communication and mobile devices. If they really need it, sure, let's think of a very expensive project that uses 5.8Ghz, big solar setups and gives people smartphones (I personally think that would be a huge mistake). But until then, here's this cheap, low-bandwidth solution that can let the village communicate at 1kbs and go on with it's traditions, which is what HF gives as well anyways. That's the idea.

[@SoapDog (Macbook)](@qv10rF4IsmxRZb7g5ekJ33EakYBpdrmV/vtP1ij5BS4=.ed25519) I've also thought of this idea of pre-made codes. I really  think that's the way to go. But would also love to test highly compressed audio, probably not feasible, but worth testing the limits. I'm thinking p2p all the way, certainly there aren't any gateways in these places anyways.

An advantage of these territories is that they are sovereign, so brazilian laws should not apply to them. And they're so remote, and deep in the forest that I can't imagine an [ANATEL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Telecommunications_Agency_(Brazil)) agent going there to try and shutdown a node that isn't complying to national laws.

So this is a great opportunity to hack LoRa to be as efficient as possible, without giving a s*** to regulations (I love that btw, can you feel the excitement of me saying that?).

 [@sam_uk](@s5nSo+j0D+tTklVi1kZqDsgEV0mLtums7UgyGAClD/0=.ed25519), if there were no constraints, what kind of tweaking could we do with LoRa to make it as efficient as possible?

Wow, that's an awesome project [@SoapDog (Macbook)](@qv10rF4IsmxRZb7g5ekJ33EakYBpdrmV/vtP1ij5BS4=.ed25519)! The use of the PVC tube + rangefinder in really smart.

I don't have a use-case for this yet. But hopefully in the future, once I'm in the ground at the forest, I'm sure such river-flooding warning system will be of huge use.

Thank you for sharing 🙏

*Qual.net* looks really awesome [@zenna](@3ZeNUiYQZisGC6PLf3R+u2s5avtxLsXC66xuK41e6Zk=.ed25519). But for this specific use case that I'm starting to journey into, the reliance on WiFi and even normal devices (phones and computers) don't fit. 

Geography has helped preserve these ways-of-life which present an alternative, thus are a threat, to the self-destructive *status quo*. But, as the forest that they depend on, they are under constant threat and are fragile, as the whole world seems to be "against" them. The geography that has protected them up until now present it's own challenges for resistance.

The concepts used by *Qual.net* and *SSB*, just to name a few, are amazing but need to be expanded to use other radio communication technologies such as LoRa or HF, and other devices such #disasterradio. Something ideal for this specific use case would be a disaster-radio + #peachcloud device. **Cheap, low-power, long-range**.

The work [@adria0](@ZFWw+UclcUgYi081/C8lhgH+KQ9s7YJRoOYGnzxW/JQ=.ed25519) and [@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519) are doing with SSB on micro-controllers are a huge step in that direction, I hope to join their efforts in the future. For now I'm experimenting with LoRa tech to learn of it's possibilities, as something as simple as text messaging could mean saving peoples lives, peoples cultures and peoples territories.

# 🎉 ![hermes butt dancing](&utxo7ToSNDhHpXpgrEhJo46gwht7PBG3nIgzlUTMmgU=.sha256) ![hermes butt dancing](&utxo7ToSNDhHpXpgrEhJo46gwht7PBG3nIgzlUTMmgU=.sha256) ![hermes butt dancing](&utxo7ToSNDhHpXpgrEhJo46gwht7PBG3nIgzlUTMmgU=.sha256) ![hermes butt dancing](&utxo7ToSNDhHpXpgrEhJo46gwht7PBG3nIgzlUTMmgU=.sha256) ![hermes butt dancing](&utxo7ToSNDhHpXpgrEhJo46gwht7PBG3nIgzlUTMmgU=.sha256) ![hermes butt dancing](&utxo7ToSNDhHpXpgrEhJo46gwht7PBG3nIgzlUTMmgU=.sha256) 🎉

That's an awesome invocation [@Nico Pace](@2AWm36HvcuOOcYeNgGgoybKXcMZx+COIf4/aAxJwnVI=.ed25519)!

We're actually going to take a first step in that direction in #coolab for Catalytics. Bruno will be connecting an esp to the LibreRouter to monitor energy and uptime.

For the use case of villages without electricity, I've been imagining an esp deep-sleeping and waking up every once in a while and turning on it's wifi, which shows a captive portal that can trigger a LibreRouter to turn on.

But because of brazilian taxes the LR is still a distant reality for most. We'd need a much cheaper version of it for it to scale.

## Quick update

[@Emmi](@5fX6QTmue/udf7tLwW25vQ63wZSENrksghBt6vfL4/I=.ed25519), I'm still trying to setup one for #moinho-mesh, but as OpenCollective only works with Stripe, which is still in Beta in Brazil, and direct bank transfer. So I still haven't anything setup yet, will take some time to do that. Thanks for the interest, it's motivating :)

![lora_test_1.jpg](&1geXTD21HAfGBkVE5+fWd5SKc1hAMrfsu3lQ3EjnTFA=.sha256)


Connecting the T-Beams with the phones using Meshtastic was pretty easy today, not sure why. Was able to do the first tests.

Went for a drive around the village with one device and left another inside my house (hay walls and roofing). Messages were coming thru fine until the hill flattened, and got on the way. Was using the default configs. Since it was getting late I didn't do any more testing. Will find good spots to do long rage tests, and lower the configs to less speed and more range. Got 600m distance for now.

# LoRa: Hello world

Thanks [@abekonge.too](@xf25ivgqN8m7GvaZBVm5lOgGgBm4SBmuTY05as9Duos=.ed25519) and [@Emmi](@5fX6QTmue/udf7tLwW25vQ63wZSENrksghBt6vfL4/I=.ed25519) :) I'm writing a really small and simple project together with our indigenous allies and hope to do some crowdfunding in the future. Anyone who would like to contribute in any way is really welcome.

I've also got a new indigenous ally from the [Krahô](https://pib.socioambiental.org/en/Povo:Krah%C3%B4) tribe. I visited a few of their villages back in 2016 with my mother and daughter, and now they're in real need for communication in the most isolated villages to resist #covid19. I started mapping their territory, but still waiting for some village gps positions, as they don't show on my map.

![t_beams.jpg](&epC7xSacqfLAGaYFc4BAGXkV3fHTkB+7i4DbAwe2y3k=.sha256)

Just acquired these cute little toys. These [TTGO-T-Beam](https://github.com/LilyGO/TTGO-T-Beam) cost way more here then elsewhere in the world. I found them used for $ 42.50 USD each, with battery, case and screen included. Once I've learned the basics I hope to acquire more boards from Aliexpress for cheaper, but brazilian customs is a pain, and I've had stuff get stuck with them before, so a bit afraid to do that.

## Testing

First firmware I tried was [Meshtastic](https://www.meshtastic.org/), as this device seems to be made for it and they have ready-to-go [bin files](https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-device/releases). Installing everything was really straight forward, but I a hard time connecting the T-Beams to the phone app. But after trying a bunch I was finally able to a get a few messages thru, but my phone battery died before I could actually do some real range testing with them. I haven't been able to get two phones connected to it since. Opened an [issue](https://github.com/meshtastic/Meshtastic-Android/issues/137), and the main developer and maintainer for the project was fast in responding.

Next up I tried #sudomesh #disasterradio. Steps:
 - `git clone git@github.com:sudomesh/disaster-radio.git`
- Install platformio cli
- `cd firmware && pio run -e ttgo-lora32-tbeam -t upload -t uploadfs`
- modify `platformio.ini`'s `monitor_speed` to this boards speed: 921600
- `pio device monitor` to see the device logs

Seem to be getting something from the board:
```GPS fix type 3
Update DB node 0xabfa10d8, rx_time=1598463937
Node status update: 1 online, 1 total
New GPS pos lat=-14.xxxx, lon=-47.xxxx, alt=887, pdop=2.350000, heading=27790.964850, sats=7
```
Although Bluetooth lights on the board are blinking, I can't seem to be able to find it on the phone. I'm guessing the firmware I'm using is for the T-Beam V0.7, and there's no support for this [T-Beam v1](https://github.com/sudomesh/disaster-radio/issues/33) (?). Here a pic of the board:

![t_beam_board.jpg](&dF9cPFd0Qj8lGGdLFxtL0au3gsQ7MARyho9ViQMRrI8=.sha256)

Would any of you awesome people from the project like to contribute to this effort?
[@nanomonkey](@+D0ku/LReK6kqd3PSrcVCfbLYbDtTmS4Bd21rqhpYNA=.ed25519) [@juul](@22YV3HX/BGClXH49ZebkcepqRpj7a9f5s0ddwhDSfxk=.ed25519) [@tunabananas](@Mq8D3YC6VdErKQzV3oi2oK5hHSoIwR0hUQr4M46wr/E=.ed25519)?

I'm very new to #lora, but really believe it can be revolutionary for defending the amazon and indigenous cultures. Having someone who understands it better to give some guidance would make things a lot smoother.

It's coming....

[The Coconut Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Coconut_Revolution) is another great example of a crisis turning into mutual-aid and collective effort for autonomy.

Let there be a storm, greater then all storms, so that there may be calm.
Thinking on the same line [@Mark](@A/B6mqn9pKzSQ+Ro+gNNubf2wN92Fsr9oT/cAUkcsL0=.ed25519)!

Hey [@SpencerHadley](@pMMUGwiEuuU1WKTQlby9SM/wkY4s0VKLqZ+P+Wmewpc=.ed25519)!

The region I was born used to have the biggest production of coffee in the world (so they said). Today it all became eucalyptus (green deserts). Unfortunately I've just recently become a coffee drinker, maybe because we had so much, I never specially had a taste for it, and know nothing about the industry. The green beans I buy are ordinary/cheap super-market options.

[@SoapDog (SPX)](@0xkjAty6RSr5uhbAvi0rbVR2g9Bz+89qiKth48ECQBE=.ed25519) probably knows more about the industry then me. Sorry I can't be of any help.

👍 Great initiative [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519)! I'm not much of a maintainer, but would love to help with the governance. Having clear core modules will make it easier to new-comers to understand the ecosystem and porting to other languages.

# Community Local Market

### 12/08/2020

[APC](https://www.apc.org/) granted #moinho-mesh $2900 USD for us to conduct emergency activities in our community. This may not seem as much, but the with the USD being valued over 5x the BRL, it's a significant amount, specially in a small village such as ours. The writing of this small project was done mainly by a group of women from the village who have been involved in organizing and maintaining a local solidarity market in the form of a WhatsApp group.

The planned activities need to be conducted by the end of the year, starting next week. Based on our 2 years experience, we decided to focus less in technology and more on educating and involving the community. As we've been too focused on technology our group hasn't been very diverse, with mostly men. So this time we have diversity as a core value, aiming to have at least 50% women and at least 50% natives. We'll be organizing an open call for anyone who would like to be involved in the activities to apply and work with us. The areas we'll be working on are: technology (mesh network, [community-server](https://github.com/MoinhoDigital/community-server), [community portal](https://github.com/moinhodigital/community-portal)), communication (documenting the process and creating a monthly newspaper) and community research (gathering economic data and educating on the use of the app).

I'll be updating the [community portal](https://moinho.network/) to include a local market page, which is built with [Gridsome](https://gridsome.org/) to make it easy to edit with Markdown. I'll be teaching at least two other people from the village on how to maintain and update the app. I'll be spreading local-servers (Router running LibreRouterOS + Single-board computers donated by [@benhylau](@Ys9lgBLC0MfPUQrbqd0hddjbjElx7ZNvtikxvMIaqgs=.ed25519)) on key places around the village to guarantee the services to be accessible. The app will also be online, as most people already have Internet access.

Then every month a group will be going door-by-door showing people how to use this local market and asking them for goods and services they would like to include in it. They will also be responsible for researching public services from town which we have the right too make use of, such as doctors, dentists, social care, etc. A small local newspaper will be designed and printed monthly, and spread around the village and the town with all this info, to really guarantee accessibility even for those who aren't into digital devices.

In total we're planning to have around 15 people working with us a few hours a month and expected to positively impact the whole village and it's surroundings. Might seem a bit ambitious for such a small grant, but after 3 meetings our whole team feels pretty positive about it.

I've been keeping an eye on the work being done by [@pospi](@Oqa5JW8rwWIVLBu38KkIb1IYz6Ax0yHuwRvLEGR1mkY=.ed25519), [@bobhaugen](@iL6NzQoOLFP18pCpprkbY80DMtiG4JFFtVSVUaoGsOQ=.ed25519), [@Lynn Foster](@g0xA0PhPzNInPFwPq3VoKcx56KZ9PFqY0QiJnKXx3co=.ed25519), [@Mayel](@aTQuVwkglxM9TABZlDBk1NF4rqfe1v6yjyH+KFb3mPI=.ed25519), [@ivan](@XZckLAZUD7b+HzVuNN1IcRBt/H7Lh9rx//WOmzhBpTc=.ed25519) and others on #valueflows UI applications. Really hope to use it and collaborate in the future.

I've recently setup an [Open Collective for Moinho](https://opencollective.com/rede-moinho), in hopes of getting some micro-donations to keep our experiments going even without any grants. [@Isabela](@Xe+wuSGAaEdwgyI/ql2WVgPG64Mqf8tVHU0VXne9Ki8=.ed25519) is making a nice drawing which I'll update the page soon when that's done. Also seeking some help on setting a Fiscal Host, maybe [@Alanna](@6OxffMLNyxkboLjCqv29WnMPhH8O3qFrcXCR6KrKcPI=.ed25519) can clarify how that works?

Errata: when I talk of cultures of the Earth, I actually mean cultures of Mother Nature. From:
> We know that Mother Nature has a culture, and it is a Native culture
> Yupiaq scholar, Oscar Kawagley

One could claim every culture is of planet Earth, but I'm not referring to the dead stone sphere floating on space.

# Connecting peoples of the Earth



For some years now I've had a growing urge to connect with my ancestry and the cultures of Earth, to help in any way I can with their resistance and learn the art of #buenvivir.

Last year's  [Kayapo Mesh](%tRXIdEOhhPhMf8ExbjsAquFPsLubCAyeGOi791QyDEQ=.sha256) project got lost in bureaucracies up until this day. This year I decided to do as I've done in the past, and go to the communities by my own means, with the goal of sharing the knowledge I had gathered in the past years in #communitynetworks and #distributedtech, but #covid19 stopped me.

But this year was awesome in the sense that I had the opportunity to connect to some key people who are fighting for indigenous cultures, and got to learn about a few different realities, even if remotely. Together we've been planning how to help communities and wrote a few communication/information related projects seeking funding.

## My current understanding of reality

![aldeias_br.gif](&hjNB6+UDQ4zUtkFpISQMNMXtNlLKaMdA76ynmKNOYVA=.sha256)
*Map with known indigenous communities and "official" territories within "brazilian" territory*

The yellow pins in the map above are a few of the known indigenous villages in brazilian territory, and the white areas are the "official", government sanctioned, territories. The relation between the presence of indigenous cultures and forest conservation is obvious.

The deeper within the forest villages are, the less likely they are to have communication, and most probable of being molested by loggers, miners and narcotic traffickers. Basic communication is a matter of survival for many. And besides only survival they **must** have the ability to speak to the outside world for themselves without depending on the state or NGOs (or myself for that matter) to speak for them. I personally also believe that giving them voice could inspire many out there who can't seem to grasp that there are alternatives to self-destructive systems.

Access to information is also crucial as most villages aren't 100% autonomous anymore, so they need to interact with the market for some basics needs. They also make use of a wide variety of modern tools, which obviously break. Many times they're able to hack the tools and make use of them in some way, but many other times the tools become obsolete, so access to technical knowledge is fundamental.

## Secure, low cost, low energy communication and information technologies

There have been amazing projects that have connected remote forest areas, such as [Rhizomatica's Hermes](https://www.rhizomatica.org/hermes/) which uses HF radio. But HF equipment is still way too expensive, energy consuming (many villages don't have electricity) and requires a ham-radio license, which makes it not scale at the pace which is [urgently](%4nTDVO9ZxZGFYNCGYnnIBLUmc3DpBBKZskbygRuwhos=.sha256) needed.

I've been really into #electronics lately, and been obsessed with the idea of building non-corporate communication/information devices. So I've been investigating #lora a lot, and how it's perfect for such remote cases, at least as a first option until high-bandwidth communication reaches them.

A single-board computer loaded with applications such as #manyverse, #ahau, #mapeo and #kolibri would serve the purpose of giving access to at least some pre-loaded information, and delay-tolerant communication of large files.

Combined these technologies offer a cheap, low energy, low tech barrier initial solution that might scale.

## My Dream

![nodes_rionegro.jpg](&2c/C6npkznEJV4G9bZl43oo22teNGm/uZUcCDsKCGfE=.sha256)

I've been using [this tool](https://link.ui.com) to locate hills near important Amazon rivers, which are likely to also have communities in the need of communication/information tech. Still need to do lots of experimentation, but I think that such LoRa mesh would be feasible.

I can't stop dreaming on going on an expedition *a la* [Schultes](https://www.amazonteam.org/maps/schultes/en/) (lol) in order to connect peoples of the Earth not only to the world, but most specially to connect them with each other and other originary cultures around the world. That's where I see the potential for great change.

I'll keep on experimenting, just wanted to throw this here, as SSB has a magic that makes dreams come true ;)

# Autonomous Community Communication Dev-Diary ✊

Continuing from %lIbjvwjLq4hBknipechzRpNLCS2YTGhiDaBHmGDRCVs=.sha256

![moinho_torre_morro.jpg](&PYLBET5WT6iQ6R5w22Dob8/WorWsPSr/ThNUmW9RfqM=.sha256)

#moinho-mesh started from the opportunity given by the anarchist #ssbc-grants process, which happened in 2018. My personal goal was to make SSB accessible to my local community thus creating our own safe piece of cyberspace. Aridi, the main native collaborator, had the goal to expand the mesh network and have the best possible Internet access for the cheapest possible price. So the actual process happened in a very organic way, going to places where non of us initially intended, aggregating many collaborators during the years.

The previous diary ended with me leaving the village for 4 months. I was a very tired of being the network's central point (of failure), and so staying away seemed like a way for other nodes to assume their roles. This generated a larger crises then I was expecting, and almost meant the end of the experiment. But other peers stepped in and held the sky from falling. This was a great lesson for all of us, and gave us an opportunity for think about why is Rede Moinho (Moinho Network) useful and important for the community.

It's time to start a new diary, with new goals, which are more realistic and incorporates our 2+ years of experience as well as opinions and ideas from other peers who have joined our efforts.

## Goals

- Develop accessible services aimed at solving community needs
- Train community members on how to install/maintain/update communication nodes (servers, routers, newspaper, etc)
- Educate community at large on how to use and contribute to local services

## Initial links

- https://github.com/MoinhoDigital/community-server
- https://github.com/MoinhoDigital/community-portal

Just disagree with the excuse for "progress":

> both life expectancy and quality of life have improved greatly over the last century in so-called first world countries

This is actually very misleading, the historic measurements for this have only been taken where state has control: mostly urban areas. Life expectancy and quality of life has improved for the urban population, that's true. But how about the rest of the non-urban world? The Chapada do Veadeiros region is known for it's UFO and alien culture. I personally had never had any sightings in 7 years. Last night was crazy though...

A star-like objects, but with a reddish light,  were disappearing and re-appearing in different parts of the sky. But nothing seemed to be moving.

In the middle of the night me and [@Isabela](@Xe+wuSGAaEdwgyI/ql2WVgPG64Mqf8tVHU0VXne9Ki8=.ed25519) woke up, the sky was clear. Our room has a 4mx2m glass door, from which we see the night sky while going to sleep, and the sunrise when waking up. Immediately I saw a star like object zig-zagging across the sky, and disappearing. For about two hours these kept appearing at random parts of the sky and disappearing.

When I closed my eye to get some more rest, with them closed I noticed something bright. When I opened them, there was a really really bright star-like object, which wasn't there before. It had a really strange glow to it, sometimes getting brighter and sometimes dimming. It stayed there until I got to sleep, close to sunrise.

I'm not a UFO aficionado, but hard to dismiss an experience like this.

Since going full-time nomadic three years ago (currently on hold - thanks 'rona) I began fastidiously tracking my monthly burn rate. I've seen a dramatic decrease in my average monthly expenditures, from about $2300 CAD when I started out to ~$950 CAD now. My goal is to keep it under $1000 CAD as a long-term average. 

The monthly amount can vary a lot depending where I am. Before all this, I split my time between Albuquerque, Paris and Florianópolis Brazil, plus usually 3-4 months full-time traveling and a short stint in Canada to see family. In each of my three most-frequented cities I had free or very affordable housing (friends, artist collectives or generous patrons). But the costs can vary greatly month to month. E.G. for the first six months of the pandemic I was stuck in Vancouver, which is a much more expensive place than where I usually inhabit. Even with a gracious friend offering me half rent for the first four months and mostly free-camping for the second two, my monthly expenses averaged closer to $1400 CAD.

This amount doesn't include long-distance travel (train where I can, or by air) or some hard costs like cameras & computers as those costs are usually covered by the projects I work on.

Just ran across this post. I agree, it's a constant battle. I've found it helpful to have certain flag words, like "we," "but," "in fact," "anyone," etc. I have a little library of these in my brain, and when they come up I try to notice, and double check if what I'm saying is framed appropriately, or a more programmed automatism that I may want to alter. This also helps for detecting my own emotional reactivity, as well as for framing opinions as opinions without any power-dynamic language. Another one I'm trying to work on is, whenever I'm about to label something, trying to check whether it's a label the subject would self-select or if it's been chosen for them without consent.

I'd love to know any tips... anything you've learned in the last few months since posting this?

I really like this philosophy [@Rabble](@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519). It feels right.

An important element for sustainability is to keep the community diverse, which means including a diverse group in what we mean by "rough consensus." In many tech-oriented communities rough consensus can lead to an overly-masculine skew, for example. It's one of the special things about SSB—lots of multi-identifying people who participate and benefit here. 

One resource I saw people continuously draw on when making my last film is Elinor Ostrom's work on governance of common-pool resources. Her findings are lightweight, useful, and come from her study of what's worked over time (vs. trying to introduce a new theory of political economy). It can be a useful touchpoint:

![Elinor Ostrom Design Principles for Sustainable Common-Pool Resources.png](&ejfgtwBpg1UHGm9JZtNQP8qrIHY8ClNSGkuZxr/deq4=.sha256)

Does anyone out there have experience with #zerotier? I'm trying to understand how to have it act as an internet gateway for all of my devices via an old Mac I have sitting in a friend's closet. 

Can anyone help me with this? [@Joey STANFORD](@bsoM86axaL6qoGHJnehEOMSbQY1rfuXeounGDqDnvzw=.ed25519)
I saw that you have a lot of ZeroTier experience?

The basic idea is to have the old Mac work as an internet gateway for outgoing traffic, and a reverse proxy for inbound traffic e.g. a basic web server on an Intel NUC running https://www.sitejs.org, as well as some ad-blocking via #pihole or similar. Once I get all that working, I'll be able to invite friends and family so we can share a bunch of private internal services and the equivalent of a small-group VPN. 

If anyone has some expertise I could really use a hand!

[@Rabble](@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519) I think the confusion comes from timing. If you were communicating these things to the non-dev SSB crowd as they are happening (in simple terms like your announcement) they would be easier to digest and discuss as things progress. Instead there are negative responses to your announcement. Why? I'd say a combination of major changes, surprise, and a lack of trust (which in my view comes from a combination of the power you hold and a lack of timely transparency). 

Two out of three of the posts you mentioned were created in reaction to your announcement, defending the choices that have been made. The third  (the detailed post by [@Aljoscha](@zurF8X68ArfRM71dF3mKh36W0xDM8QmOnAS5bYOq8hA=.ed25519) goes in-depth; but it doesn't reference #planetary at all. At the end it states "Any new self-describing data format to become part of SSB must support feed identifiers and message identifiers for all prior formats." If a non-dev reads this, it creates a sense that anyone making changes would take on the responsibility of keeping things compatible—but your announcement gave the impression of branching off from the main SSB community, which is a surprise.

I think that's the main idea. If you want the community to come along, I think it's on you (not someone else) to: 
1. Regularly communicate in a transparent fashion that allows for discussion and dialogue before and during the decision-making process; and, 
2. As [@elavoie](@IgYpd+tCtXnlE2tYX/8rR2AGt+P8svC98WH3MdYAa8Y=.ed25519) has said, take on the burden of interoperability as changes are made going forward. 

You appear to be doing the second, so the first should be fairly straightforward I think?

[@Rabble](@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519) In the absence of governance, transparency can help prevent shocks and allow the existing ad-hoc governance and tacit knowledge systems to function with better information. 

What if, while governance and some of these issues are sorted out, you take a posture of more transparency? I think if you were to spend some of your creative energy on keeping a deeper and more regular dialogue with the SSB community, it would help alleviate the frustration that's flowing out of an (otherwise positive) announcement like this. For example, as other devs have done, you could post regular updates on feature ideas for comment and discussion with the possibility of adapting your decisions. Its not a formal structure, but a conversation with an invested community. Especially things like a new encoding format are extremely significant, as are philosophical choices about whether to include new members in the existing SSB community ecosystem. It's good that you're discussing these things with other devs. Perhaps take it a step further and sum up these discussions with a post for the wider community to allow greater circulation and elaboration?

It seems like in your posts these technical / philosophical / policy / values issues are somewhat conflated and the thinking to us outsiders isn't clear. This leads to frustration and confusion. If you spend more time on transparency of both your thinking process, decisions and ideas on a regular basis, it will help keep these discussions productive and useful to the community, and help keep the tone and decision-making positive (which I truly believe is your intention).

I haven't see the Estonia federated system docs, and a quick search didn't lead me anywhere fruitful. Care to link?

As for #dfinity ... I think the success of LAMP is the federation of the platform projects. Linux, Apache, MySQL and PHP were all independent projects that when combined created something great. I'm distrustful of a single provider trying to accomplish everything. Especially when... ugh, blockchain...

# Web3 needs a P2P LAMP stack

For #web3 to really take off there’s a whole host of systems and tools that need to be built:
- P2P addressing & access
- Identity
- e2e-everything
- Federation, sharding, and division of storage & compute in a way that allows specialization without creating centralization

This is basic infrastructure required before a diversity of projects, ecosystems and communities can flourish. Some of these challenges have been or are in the midst of being solved, but none have yet come together as a complete ecosystem, sufficient enough to be form a nascent Web3 equivalent of a LAMP stack or JAMstack.

One thing I’ve noticed in my surfing around the P2P and federated world: the existing system of NATs, IPv4 and DNS is a major limitation to the P2P web. There needs to be some kind of decentralized DNS to make human-friendly the machine-readable keys of Web3. Projects like Yggdrasil or #Hyperswarm are essential building blocks—tools that allow computers to connect directly to each other.

As the toolsets are developed, three significant issues appear:

1. Security
2. Privacy
3. Performance

Security: as soon as you have direct access to any single machine on the web, it’s available as a direct target to anyone globally.

Privacy: a single global address tied per machine or client is tantamount to an identity, which makes it a target for tracking, dragnet surveillance, targeted hacking etc.

Performance: it's a mobile world. On mobile you need access to what’s most recent and relevant, and it must be performant over a constrained connection on a small device. Yet you still need to access and search your whole archive. This quickly becomes a limitation of on mobile devices, especially when #onboarding new users who essentially have to download the entire reachable P2P web before they can view it. This is a significant design problem for the P2P web. (The Fastmail folks said it elegantly in reference to not including e2e encryption their new [JMAP email spec](https://jmap.io/#end-to-end-encryption): you don’t want to have to download your entire inbox in order to search it.)

I’m excited to see if something akin to the LAMP stack emerges for Web3 that has useable answers to these questions. #scuttlebutt is getting close, as the community grapples with solutions for nascent mobile apps while keeping things P2P. The concept of pubs and having the tech mirror real social networks is unique in the P2P world. I’m excited to see what the community comes up with.
[@kas](@RuNxm8SRujPcJx6GjtTQHp6hprAFv5voEkcvoAkB8Pk=.ed25519) Beat me to it by 5 seconds! Yes, Hashbase should do what you need and is free for basic needs and reasonable if you need more.

Congrats on the funding! Very excited about the ideas that seem to be forming in your group. Agree wholeheartedly with your initial focus communities—I think there's excellent values overlap, and you have a community that is used to being active and taking responsibility for their role, which I think will lead to healthy growth.

Excited to see what you come up with and how it all evolves!

This has been a pain point for me also—decentralized collaboration is not mature right now. Kind of ironic to need to use Google Docs for a decentralized project.

Graphite Docs is not yet mature. CryptPad is promising but does not yet do spreadsheets. So... self-hosted is still the best option. In that realm the best I've seen is Nextcloud + OnlyOffice. OnlyOffice is working on a blockchain-based decentralized collaboration system for their desktop apps, but not sure when that will be available.

So... it's a space with lots of room for a solid new entrant.

I like the idea of FOSS / indie / open-governance way to donate. I think the mental heuristic of automated payments, though, is too bolt-on for the existing web. I don't think people get it, or if they do it doesn't fill a "job to be done" for them—the same reason Flattr struggled to get traction.

I think Patreon is on to something because they help build a relationship between the creator and the audience. It's specific, explicit, and low-friction. On-boarding is simple, and once you're in the Patreon system, adding a new creator is ultra-low friction. There's more of a conversation and choice instead of a generalized algorithm.

Instead of a bolt-on to the old web like Flattr, I think the opportunity lies in this emergence of a new, independent web (through SSB, DAT and other protocols) to have the consideration of paying content creators be a basic element of the social contract. Making it frictionless to support someone you like, who's contributing to the commons or in some other way through their content, can be the next step. For example, say I've liked [@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519)'s posts a few times, and I see he's made a request for support via #SSB-patreon, it's just a click or two to give to him on a monthly basis.

I think that's the promise of an indie / decent web—that not only does the content flow freely without censorship, but also the means to make that content flows from those that have to those that need.

I like what I'm hearing. Again, I'm not advocating for a #cooperative model. I'm supportive—I think we're on a similar wavelength. Money needs to flow through the system to feed all of its parts and then flow back to the source. It's what will make the thing vital and sustainable. There should be a similar flow for governance—listening and learning, yes, but not getting in the way of the flow of action. I see evidence of you wanting to do all that, and that's good! 

I don't care what model you use TBH. We wouldn't need have such a strong need for socialism, co-ops and the like as a counterpoint if those with a head start in capitalism played nice all of the time.

#Librepay / #Patreon are good current approaches, but Librepay has low uptake (so high friction to create a new account etc.) and Patreon is your typical centralized corporate structure, with artist's funding subject to the whims of a founder/CEO. So, a decentralized / indie approach would be a nice alternative.

I think that keeping the funding close to the social networks that support it is also good. There's a tendency for Patreon to want you to hide content behind its walls as an incentive. I think it's better to let the content be out there in the world, but for that to work the funding model needs to be very low-friction and close-in to the existing interactions between artists and their supporters.

Thanks for the update [@rabble](@5fYRrgyJON0r0R9SPrK0oxR1XKhqNXqiN0FBX+MgfH4=.ed25519). It's good to see your thoughts out in the open and I think continuing that process as your thoughts develop will benefit the whole community.

For those who are against content monetization... I would *love* it if y'all had a real solution that isn't:
1. Selling a product
2. Advertising

... because as someone who works on creating content full-time, it's really, really difficult for me buy food, pay rent and pay my crew. I'm certainly less well-off than most of the people who watch my films—and I'm OK with that, but anything like #verse that makes a try at a #sustainable #decentralized #indie content ecosystem is a very positive move in my books.

Right now content-makers like me are stuck in a very difficult situation. Either submit to the big three and build value on their platforms, develop your own products/advertising/funding platform, or work with the traditional media ecosystems (a la Netflix, HBO etc.) None of these are attractive solutions if independence and freedom of expression are what you're after.

So, I'm supportive of #verse giving it a shot and seeing what they come up with. At the same time, I'm happy if someone has some better ideas on how a #documentary filmmaker like me can get what I need to live while making content. Until then, I'm very curious to see what [@rabble](@5fYRrgyJON0r0R9SPrK0oxR1XKhqNXqiN0FBX+MgfH4=.ed25519), [@Tom Coates](@7A2ZxHX+WyIVezulnt0FogzeUVWLq3YHmtX3r7ja4Fw=.ed25519) and the crew come up with.

Alexandria Bombach sums up the #documentary dilemma perfectly: 

> I lost a piece of my own humanity in order to get that shot. The part of my humanity that would throw the camera aside and hug this person. People cry during this moment of the film. Does that make it worth it?

https://www.talkhouse.com/with-steady-hands/

A great film worth watching if you can.

[@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) I found out about #ssb via a long chain that started with a Facebook link to [Aral](https://ar.al), who was writing about #DAT, which led me to #Beaker, which led me via long chain through [@paul](@hxGxqPrplLjRG2vtjQL87abX4QKqeLgCwQpS730nNwE=.ed25519)'s old work to [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) and... here I am. So I didn't have a personal invite even though I feel comfortable and "at home" here. 

I was having trouble finding my people online, and stumbling in the open door of a pub was how I found my way here. One of the ways tech can be a barrier to new people adopting it is if it depends too much on being friends with tech-minded folks, especially in disadvantaged or disenfranchised communities. I think the pub / community centre idea is more than just a cute metaphor—it's a model for something that's quite effective for IRL social networks, and something we can learn from.
Yep, feel free - send me a PM
[@freemarky__](@RXyQPWSV7g8RtTX1bO/VojWlGipS+VPlxu+FHJJtJB0=.ed25519) Broadcast looks cool! I'd be happy to help test.
Welcome! Even if it's not your current status, glad to see some other #nomad folks here :smile:

I really like what [@Ivar](@wOpevKYrGQKtOmovG1AONicgo3sIhoqbMPj1QMcfRDM=.ed25519) is proposing. Making pubs super simple to set up and slightly more useful in the way they mirror natural social networks would be, I think, a big boost for Scuttlebutt adoption.

To go slightly beyond this, to have a simple [Raspberry Pi image](%37IT5j2DOdGgggz8tS+zLtP0lkeJdSbeg5WNzYxthoI=.sha256) or an app that can be easily installed & configured for a family on the ubiquitous home NAS servers I see popping up all over (such as Synology and Qnap, often used for hosting Plex).
Thanks for sharing. I can relate... a lot for me ends up being about community support and doing my best to exercise (on top of all the diet etc. that you mention). You're not alone.
Love that it's portable & accessible. Is there any way to access the networking stack directly so other apps can be used? Right now it looks like you have to use their proprietary app.

Raspbian I'd say - though a custom image would be fine if needed. What I'd be most interested in is a super-simple "just works" starter kit, that you can then customize if needed / if you're curious. I think decent tech has a better chance of taking off if we make the on-boarding as simple as possible for those who want to use the tech (vs. those who like to tinker or build)
This looks fantastic! I'd love to come help out when I'm next in Spain.

#art #documentary #film #photography #writing #journalism #nomad
A pre-built image for a stock #raspberrypi would be a fantastic tool for spreading the scuttlebutt love...

Hello all—what are the current favoured alternatives to #Patreon that might help a film artist like myself build a community that shares energy and currency in exchange for my (& my crew's) labour on #documentary projects?
Congrats!!
I'm traveling in the south of Brazil for a few weeks, based from Porto Alegre. Anyone in the area? Any recommendations in or around the city?

I don't think co-ops are necessarily the answer. It's more important to look at what whether your system is regenerative,  regardless of which structure or governance model you choose. Does it respect the existing community? Does wealth flow back to the commons on which the new wealth was built? Etc.

I think you could structure investment in a way that respects these principles. Social impact investing may be an additional route to examine, common in B-corp land.

I loved Primer. Upstream Color was an ambitious second take.

Camera crew pay is an interesting topic. In a major centre in Canada I typically pay a day rate, between $350/d (for admin help) up to about $1000/d (for an experienced cinematographer). A typical documentary crew is four: me (director), field producer, camera, sound. Add the equipment and a shooting day is $4000-$7000/day on the low end and goes much, much higher. For example, there's a sequence of a string quartet in the film—we paid union standard wages for the quartet, plus rented the recording studio, plus the studio staff, plus a high-end DP & equipment, meals, some transport, etc. That day probably cost us closer to $22,000 CAD. 

Part of the economics of all of this is that camera crews work a handful of days a month. They spend a good 50% of their time not working, between gigs, networking to find more work. Plus there's high capital costs for equipment that's always being updated and renewed.

There's lots more I can go into, but it's tough to make a film for less than $150k (two people) or about $350k (four-person crew & proper finishing).

As for a way to access the film... how to bring back financially what's necessary to put out in the first place to produce a film is a major technological and cultural hurdle for documentary producers right now. Current not-so-great options include:
1. Sell to Netflix / a distributor and be subject to their exclusivity and restrictions, in exchange for a partial return on the cost of production
2. Attempt to crowdfund / sell directly to viewers (but when's the last time you paid for a film?)
3. Raise money from funds willing to lose the large up-front cost of making a film, and give the film away (if it's hard to raise $200k to give away to something as amazing as #ssb, think how hard it is to raise 2-5x that to make a film)

It's an impossible problem, and I think if places like #scuttleville can solve it in the micro, it can start a cultural & technological transformation where hopefully the next generation of visual storytellers coming up will be able to find a sustainable way of living without having to sell their art/community-crafted knowledge as an asset within the capitalist system (which is the solution I'm stuck with for the moment).

However... if anyone has any amazing ideas on how I can pay my crew and pay my rent while making these films... I'm totally for it!

Hey [@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) —yep, spot on. The film aligns directly with what you could call a gardening approach. Big ideas have to work in the here and now (something all of the stories in the film wrestle with). Curious if what pushed your buttons in the trailer is Ben's inclusion and your Loomio connections, or something else in the trailer? For example one of our main stories in the film links people on the street with mental health / addiction issues into work that's profitable and dignified while being appropriately supportive. There's all kinds of issues... I could go on for days about it if you want to discuss.

Either way... my goal isn't to promote the film, but to highlight John's work because I think it's relevant to #verse. It's a model that can guide here, now, with whatever structure or governance model is under consideration to see if it fits what the community wants to build.

Instead of posting on #new-people I thought I'd dive right in.

After digging around a bit I was immediately fascinated by the #verse conversation started by [@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519). I have some experience in this area. I recently completed a [film](http://www.aneweconomy.ca) on how groups cooperate and collaborate in value exchange and wealth—including #loomio, contact with the #enspiral folks, #Sensorica, The Embassy Network and many others.

The filming process exposed me to [John Fullerton](www.capitalinstitute.org)'s work, which is highly relevant to the development of #verse and the growth of the #ssb community. John's an ex-managing director at JP Morgan who deeply understands economics from a practical viewpoint—both extractive capital and something better, a pattern he's calling Regenerative Economics. He's dedicated the last few decades to finding the principles & patterns of sustainable economic systems. His group has developed [eight principles](http://capitalinstitute.org/8-principles-regenerative-economy/) (and a few useful [stories](http://fieldguide.capitalinstitute.org/stories.html) ) that could profoundly assist in guiding what #verse becomes.

For example, two principles that are relevant as #verse emerges—a regenerative system:

> (2) Views wealth holistically: True wealth is not merely money in the bank. It must be defined and managed in terms of the well-being of the whole, achieved through the harmonization of multiple kinds of wealth or capital, including social, cultural, living, and experiential. It must also be defined by a broadly shared prosperity across all of these varied forms of capital. The whole is only as strong as the weakest link.

(For #verse, this could mean going beyond a B-corp to make sure that profit and wealth generated by building on top of the commons flows back into the commons.)

> (5) Honors Community and Place: Each human community consists of a mosaic of peoples, traditions, beliefs, and institutions uniquely shaped by long-term pressures of geography, human history, culture, local environment, and changing human needs. Honoring this fact, a Regenerative Economy nurtures healthy and resilient communities and regions, each one uniquely informed by the essence of its individual history and place.

(In this case, honoring the p2p nature of scuttlebutt where the technical infrastructure mirrors the social fabric creates possibilities for innovative and potentially groundbreaking ways of organizing a business.)

I'd highly encourage [@rabble](@vzoU7/XuBB5B0xueC9NHFr9Q76VvPktD9GUkYgN9lAc=.ed25519), [@Tom Coates](@7A2ZxHX+WyIVezulnt0FogzeUVWLq3YHmtX3r7ja4Fw=.ed25519) and others who are looking into how to create a healthy engagement to build wealth in this #commons / community to have a read of John's [research (whitepaper - PDF)](http://capitalinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/2015-Regenerative-Capitalism-4-20-15-final.pdf) and possibly reach out to him (I can make an introduction if needed).

The difference between a well-structured, well-governed economic engagement and an extractive one is profound. I feel if the #ssb community can get this right with #verse, it may be a very positive example for others to aspire to.

Since I'm not sure exactly how conversations work yet here, tagging a few people who seem to be most engaged with this conversation: [@elavoie](@IgYpd+tCtXnlE2tYX/8rR2AGt+P8svC98WH3MdYAa8Y=.ed25519) [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) [@Alanna](@6OxffMLNyxkboLjCqv29WnMPhH8O3qFrcXCR6KrKcPI=.ed25519) [@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519) [@mix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519)
My first few moments with this network have been very enjoyable... a sensation akin to my first steps onto the web 20 years ago. Excited to see where this leads!
Yes! Excited for #manyverse to come to iOS with multi-device / sameAs support. I think it will be a turning point for the Scuttlebutt network.
